151065431.review:
Nier: Automata is the child of an uncompromised vision

First impressions were mixed for me. The character design of our lead protagonist, kanata wielding, maid outfit wearing female combat android 2B, leaned into its anime roots with impressive conviction. Your mileage may vary, I was interested. The first hints of the plot were intriguing, and the frenetic combat system impresses with tight, reactive controls and a rich collection of scenarios and game modes. 

The color scheme, on the other hand, limits itself to muted colors and sparse textures, giving the entire game world a worn, washed-out feeling. The choice of having about an hour of tutorial without the opportunity of a save point seems weirdly cruel and antiquated, especially because that first hour has a really steep difficulty curve. Said tutorial also neglects to introduce any of the RPG elements in the game’s collection. So when I was finally let loose in its modestly dimensioned open world, I wasn’t quite sold on it. 

Things improve at a slow but steady rate, though. A growing stable of weapons and other upgrades bring variety and novelty into the combat. The spectacle fighter mechanics click somewhat with the bullet hell shooter elements that show up whenever one of the enemies has a gun.  The plot picks up and maintains steam on its way to some very weird and intriguing places. Side quests surprise with quirkiness and and often surprising depth. 

Questions remain, though: Why is almost every enemy a variation on the theme “rusty beer can”? Why is our protagonist so cold towards her enchantingly naive sidekick? Why do I have the option to kill my protagonist by deinstalling her OS? 

On the gameplay side of things, it’s wasn’t smooth sailing either: Over time, I settled on a combination of weapons and upgrades that broke the difficulty curve, and at that point, combat started becoming samey, except for the impressive boss fights. The dialogue seemed stilted and inelegant. The game kept its fast travel mechanics locked for a little too long and its ultimate gear upgrades were a little too grindy to obtain to bother with for me. 

And then the game ended with a moderately satisfying ending, dumped me into the main menu, winked at me and gesticulated towards the “New Game” button. Which dumped me into the shoes of emo twink 9S, who had so far been the sidekick. 

And so I went through the whole story again, but with a lot more context this time. Also, there were instances in the first playthrough where 2B and 9S had split up, and the stuff 9S was up to during these times threw an entirely new light on things. Gameplay added a lot more bullet hell shooter elements, and the weird, impenetrable little plot kept growing and changing and turning into this epic greek tragedy, until a terrifying climax left me shaken, looking at the main menu and hitting the “New Game”-Button again, impatient to what would be different this time. 

Everything, as it turned out: playthrough 3 hides the second part of the game. The plot keeps escalating and escalating, the existential dread is turned up to eleven. Time ceases to have any meaning. The fourth wall shudders and cracks. Several tens of hours filled with escalations and re-interpretations later, the game finds a suitably weird, thought-provoking and mind-blowing ending. 

And then, the god-damn end credits turn into a unique, sublime mind fuck of an EXPERIENCE I would on the pain of death not dare spoil, but which every gamer on this planet should experience.                                             Seriously, it’s that good.

And when I was done picking my chin up from the floor, something amazing happened: All the weirdness, all the inexplicably awkward design choices revealed themselves to be the outgrowths and consequences of a uniquely strong artistic vision. Seriously, I can practically see the contempt on Yoko Taro’s face while he blazes past every fork on the road that would increase player comfort but even slightly tarnish the coherence and integrity of his creation. I mean, I realize this was a work of a small army of creative talents, but they must have had a mind meld going on in that studio of theirs, because I, at least, really felt like I connected to a person through this one, a visionary artist with a few blind spots in map and UI design, and maybe a bit too much into waifish maids. 

The Credits. Man, those credits. 

TLDR: The story people have played this long ago, as every one of them should. The gameplay tribe should know that the offerings here are serviceable to good, but you’ll get to be gobsmacked with the rest of us, and isn’t that kind of experience the reason we’re here, after all? I know I am.

150780624.review:
It kinda kills me to leave a negative review because the story and world building are both amazing but so far it's been a really frustrating experience for all the wrong reasons.

1) Soo little effort has been put in to make the PC port run well, all the controls are optimized for console and provide far too few options to adjust. The worst of which is, and i kid you not, if you move your mouse in a circle you start petting your pod/droid which causes you to stand dead still for 4 seconds even if you are mid combat. This has happened HUNDREDS of times already for me and caused very annoying deaths, and there is no way to turn it off. I also really dislike the dodge being a WASD double click and can't change that either.

2) The camera switches between 3D, top-down and side view. When this works well it can make platforming smoother but most of the time it just feels like the game is taking control away from you and makes it harder to look at what you want to.

3) Bullet-hell gameplay sucks. I'm here for the story and combat. To me these sections feel like a boring and unforgiving mini-game.

4) Tutorial is way too hard, long and contains no checkpoints. At the end there is a boss fight who has several insta-kill attacks that kick you back 30 minutes of grueling tutorial with unstoppable dialogue. And the strange thing is that it gets so much easier once the main game stars. The tutorial has literally the sharpest difficulty spike and least forgiving save system in the whole game for no reason.

5) Your sidekick loves pushing you off ledges and getting in front of people you want to talk to and chests you want to open, causing you to speak to him instead.

6) Melee combat is more fun, but the game heavily incentivizes you to just constantly run from the enemy while shooting backwards.

As I started out saying, I really want to like this game, the philosophical themes really resonate with me, the writing is clever and the world pretty. All in all I will probably finish the game for these reasons but for a AAA game that has been out for so long there are just a stupid amounts of annoyances.

150523001.review:
This is a no spoiler review. I Heard good things about the game around when it was released but didn't play it. 6 months ago I started to listen to the game soundtrack and fell in love with it. A month ago I started playing the game and recently finished it. Now when I listen to the soundtrack, it's hard not to cry. This game is a gut-wrenchingly sad but beautiful tale that has left me to spend a good deal of time putting the pieces together, contemplating what the intended message of the story actually is. It's by now means a perfect game, and many of the "flaws" are a matter of taste or  opinion, but if you enjoy the opening act, chances are you'll enjoy the entirety of the game. 

For me, the soundtrack alone would have made the game worth playing. I listen to a lot of music variety and the score from this game is very close to the top of anything I've heard.

 The movement and fighting mechanics feel very good but I think they are under-utilized. Given that the game has 4 difficulty levels, the majority of fighting mechanics feel superfluous and entirely unnecessary, though I only played the game on level 2 (normal). Mostly it comes down to whether you can evade/jump at the correct time to dodge attacks and how quickly you can button mash the same 3 basic attacks to hack through enemies. I enjoyed the fighting mechanics, but I don't see myself going back and repeating the game at a higher difficulty level. 

The side content is interesting and often tries to hide some deeper meaning within, but is mostly unnecessary to the overall game. That's the curse of open-world style games, I guess. Most side quests have some amusing/charming elements to them, but sometimes they just feel like a slog and weren't very well polished. It sort of feels like the director focused his attention on the main quest and let the interns work on the side-quests, only ensuring that the writing agreed with the overall plot of the game. In other words, they are hit-or-miss. 

The main factor that makes this game a massive hit is the plot and storytelling of the main quest line. It takes the ideas of many Western philosophers and presents them in a way that is emotional and entertaining. It tries to make you think about life. And death. And this is where you will either love or hate this game. I'm not even sure there is an in-between. The opening act should determine whether it's a game you'll enjoy. Obviously I loved it, and will be returning to play some of the director's other games...

150411073.review: Entertaining (although shallow) story, fun combat, unique bosses, interesting side quests. But between the unique bosses are a lot of running around, grinding, repetitive mobs, misleading maps, non-toggleable quest markers, not-very-useful fast travel that always seems to be disabled for the places you need to go, and invisible walls blocking you from travelling intuitive direct routes. 150410640.review:
Nier: Automata isn't just a game; it's a symphony of gameplay and music that orchestrates a mesmerizing journey through a post-apocalyptic world. PlatinumGames' combat finesse, a seamless fusion of hack-and-slash and shoot-'em-up brilliance, turns every encounter into a visceral dance of blades and bullets. Keiichi Okabe's musical masterpiece acts as the emotional backbone, enhancing the narrative and propelling the gaming experience to unparalleled heights.

Yet, amidst the brilliance, there are occasional hiccups. The camera angles, usually a dance partner in the combat spectacle, can be a bit rebellious during intense sequences, occasionally disrupting the fluidity. The PC port, while serviceable, imposes a 60Hz cap, leaving high-refresh-rate monitor enthusiasts yearning for a more visually fluid experience.

However, Nier: Automata's allure goes beyond these technical quibbles. With only Ending A under my belt, the promise of multiple endings teases at unexplored narrative depths, beckoning players to return for more. The game's ability to seamlessly intertwine music and gameplay creates an unforgettable symphony that resonates, making Nier: Automata a must-experience for those who crave a unique and captivating adventure in the realm where the extraordinary meets the eccentric.

150211514.review:
If you came to the store page because of the hype around the game or because you think 2B is hot, then this review is for you.

2B is hot. The game is not.

I solely believe that everyone that claims to love the game just love the character design and music, because that is the only strong point that Nier:Automata has to offer. 

Anything that is said about beautiful scenarios and atmosphere is overstimated. 

The scenarios present are as little as four that I will not spoil because god knows you will buy the game anyways if you are as far into the reviews to get into a negative one.

But keep in mind that while this games tries to be a hack-and-slash, a bullethell, an RPG and a story-rich adventure, it does all of those and also fails at all of those. 

It's a jack-of-all-trades and master of no one.

I'd be positive about it if it wasn't by the fact that the main hook is the story. 

And I kid you not, this game has the most foreshadowed, predictable plot twist I have ever seen. So much that I was left out feeling that there had to be another twist, something else because by the end of it I felt that it was telling me that the Earth was round and expecting me to feel astonished by that fact.

If you are coming here not for the positive reasons I listed above and are looking for a story rich original game..., keep looking. 

This one has nothing to offer but round butts and a funny twink. For most, that was enough to give this game a positive review.

But not for me.

149948168.review:
NieR: Automata offers an immersive experience that stands out as a masterpiece in the gaming world. The game captivates players not only with its gameplay mechanics, but also with in-depth storytelling and an atmospheric world.

The game's story is unusual and complex. This epic story about the struggle between humanity and artificial intelligence transforms the game from a mere entertainment tool into a thought-provoking work of art. The in-depth character development and plot twists draw players into a labyrinth of thought.

Graphically, NieR: Automata is a stunning visual feast. The game's world comes to life with exquisitely designed environments and detailed character models. Visual effects and the overall aesthetic of the game provide players with an unforgettable visual experience.

The music further enhances the atmosphere of the game. The music changes according to the various moments of the game, adding emotional depth. The fast-paced music during action scenes increases the excitement of the game, while the touching melodies and instruments during melancholic moments give players the opportunity to make an emotional connection.

Another remarkable feature of the game is its gameplay mechanics. A fast-paced combat system and a variety of weapon options provide players with an experience that suits a variety of play styles. These mechanics increase the replayability of the game and provide long-lasting enjoyment.

However, like any game, NieR: Automata may be subject to some criticism. Technical issues, poor performance and some bugs can negatively affect the gameplay experience. However, the overall experience of the game outweighs these technical issues.

In conclusion, NieR: Automata is not just a game, but a work of art and storytelling. With its in-depth story, stunning visuals and emotional soundtrack, it offers players an unforgettable experience. This game has earned a rightful place among the extraordinary works in the gaming world.

149824215.review:
[h1] A Masterpiece That Pushes Boundaries [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



Nier: Automata is a game that defies all expectations and breaks new ground in the action RPG genre. It is a stunning example of what happens when a talented team comes together to create something unique and thought-provoking.

The game dives deep into complex themes of existence, consciousness, and the human condition. It blurs the line between androids and humans, forcing players to question what it means to be alive. The storytelling is incredible, with multiple perspectives and branching paths that keep you engaged and emotionally invested.

Visually, Nier: Automata is a treat for the eyes. The environments are beautifully designed, ranging from post-apocalyptic cityscapes to serene and mysterious landscapes. The attention to detail is astounding, creating a believable and immersive world.

What truly sets Nier: Automata apart is its combat. The fast-paced and fluid action is a joy to experience. From hacking enemy robots to engaging in intense boss battles, the combat never gets repetitive or boring. The game constantly keeps you on your toes, challenging you to master different playstyles and abilities.

The soundtrack deserves a special mention, as it perfectly complements the gameplay and enhances the emotions conveyed by the story. The haunting melodies and epic compositions stay with you long after you've put the game down.

Furthermore, the game provides a significant amount of replay value. Multiple playthroughs offer different perspectives and expand on the narrative, revealing hidden secrets and uncovering additional layers of the story.

One small drawback is the occasional technical hiccups and performance issues on the PC version, which can hinder the overall experience. However, the game's strengths far outweigh this minor inconvenience.

In conclusion, Nier: Automata is an absolute gem that pushes boundaries and challenges conventional storytelling. It is a masterclass in art direction, gameplay mechanics, and narrative depth. If you're a fan of thought-provoking stories and unique gameplay experiences, Nier: Automata is a must-play.

149693699.review:
Here's what's good about Nier: Automata:
The heavily detailed open world, combined with somewhat fourth wall breaking gameplay mechanics makes for an extremely immersive experience
The combat system is surprisingly deep. The fast, fluid movement feels so satisfying to play. Hacking is also very fun!
The graphics are incredible and the music is god-tier
This game is so full of content, and there are secrets everywhere. Rather than putting out a half-baked, unfinished mess, PlatinumGames really put their heart and souls into making a completed game, and it definitely shows.

There are a few bad parts too:
Getting all achievements is a grind
Sometimes this game tries to be too immersive. For example, there are many long sections of the game where the pause menu is completely disabled, so you cannot save or load data. Meaning your only option is to hard reset the game, which will cause you to lose progress! This is just poor game design.
The "Hard" difficulty is unbalanced. I chose to play the game on this difficulty thinking it would make combat more interesting, but really all it does is make enemies hit 3x harder. So for anything but the weakest enemies, you're basically a one-shot kill.

Overall, the bad parts that I mentioned are extremely minor compared to all the good things about Nier: Automata. It's a well-rounded, complete game, and as someone who has never played a game like this before, I was constantly surprised with every new thing I saw. I highly recommend playing it!

149507167.review:
Hope you like crashing. This game has not been fully fixed with updates. The PC port had a lot of known issues when it was first released and when I originally started playing you had to download a MOD to fix the most basic issues (FAR). I was told the game has received multiple updates since that time that should fix the problems, but I still experience random crashes playing this game. I have zero stability issues with my PC and no issues with anything else crashing. Brand new clean install of Windows 10, Latest Nvidia drivers and the game still closes itself periodically. There are no error messages or any indication that anything is wrong with the game. I'm playing on a 12600K, 3060ti and gen4 nvme drive. The crashes happen at completely random points so sometimes I may get 20 minutes of playing in before the game closes and other times maybe i can play for an hour. Did I mention the game only lets you save and very specific areas and the autosave is very unforgiving? You will be replaying a lot of content, which brings me to the game itself. 



This game gets in the way of itself. I do not find the repeated playthrough method of story telling very enjoyable. When I first beat route A and popped into route B to start playing 90% of the exact game again, but this time as 9S I almost immediately lost interest in the game. The new content was sprinkled so few and far between and was things like, you may see one 20 second cutscene you didn't see on your first playthrough and then are back to the same quests, the same horrible to traverse map, (the map system in this game is also awful), killing the same enemies and following the same main quest. I stopped playing for over two years because of this, but since I do enjoy many aspects of this game I decided to give it another shot recently. After beating playthrough B, playthrough C starts with a huge difficulty spike. I was level 40 upon entering the C playthrough and the lowest enemies I was encountering were 45. Many of the enemies were all the way up to level 60 and could nearly one shot me. The game floods you with extremely annoying tactics to inflate difficulty like making you lose the ability to move your character, lose the ability to attack, lose the ability to jump, lose the ability to see (98% of your screen a massive red blob of pixels while you're fighting huge mobs of extremely over leveled enemies). Even with this I still pushed through, because I was determined to beat this game. I am now quite close to the end and still can't finish the game thanks to it randomly closing. There is a lot to like about this game, the world is interesting, the actual gameplay itself is fun and varied, the characters are likeable, etc, but so much gets in the way of just experiencing the story. Many herald it as one of the best games ever because of this, but I do not find this an enjoyable method of experiencing a game especially in this day in age where I have very limited time to play games and an endless backlog. 

````` 

Just to be fair I am updating my review. I tried to continue the game since I was desperate to finally finish this on my Garuda Linux install through Steam and it actually worked fine without crashing. Not sure what the deal is with the quirks I was having on my Windows install. The game overall is pretty great and I am happy I was able to see it through to the end and experience the ending. I would probably overall still recommend playing the Xbox version though so you don't have to deal with these potential crash issues. The game is definitely worth experiencing. I am going to go ahead and change my recommendation to recommended.

149183119.review:
This is a beautiful, artistic game with a strong message. For that, it is worth playing. The combat system is very crisp and free-flowing. If the visual style seems dreary, it's because the style is part of the message. Even if there is some repetitiveness, it's worth playing to the end to see how the story unfolds. 

It's also worth playing Nier Replicant before this game to get more of the story. There are some important references to that game in this one. Nier Replicant (the remaster) is not as crisp as this one - it's an older game - but I think it has a stronger and more emotional story. It depends on your preference. I consider Nier Replicant a masterpiece, and this one comes in second to the first as a very original, artistic and well polished game.

Definitely something different and worth playing. I hope they make yet another Nier sometime in the future.

I'm only a handful of stages in, but this is easily one of the most dramatic use of screen movement I've seen in any game. Every battle you're in feels impactful, from the overall just stunning visuals, to the unique rising music. 

It's a third person action-adventure RPG with bullet hell combat elements. Think Devil May Cry meets any of the dodge and shoot projectiles before they overwhelm you genre. 

Battles will go from your typical third person action combat to a top down camera where you must bullet hell, to then put you in a sidescroller style locked camera, to shifting you into a aircraft to do your typical bullet hell things, to then have that aircraft transform into a gundam to do the top down bullet hell again. 

It sounds like a lot, but it's so seemless, it teaches you fairly well and exposes you do different elements early. Progression is fantastic. Bosses are absolutely immersive. There's an open world element. That's not even touching on the actual plot or story for the world, which is equally interesting and very unique. Combat is tight and fun. A fair amount of customization options.

I waited way too long to play this. I've hit the 6hr mark, haven't even scratched the surface of the game and already see exactly why people hail this game as a masterpiece. It was crafted with love, with attention to detail, with depth that you'd only get from PS1-PS2 era JRPGs in which the world is shameless exactly what the creator wants it to be and a story to tell regardless of how niche it might be. It becomes very clear some of the commentary being made about various subjects early on. 

The only advice I give is that you have to work for your first chance to save. Make sure you're committed enough to get there. It's not incredibly difficult (I'm on normal difficulty), but I definitely got careless thinking  I'd probably respawn. Nope, start the game from the beginning. I think the method is intended though, because after restarting it took me a quarter of the time to get back to where I was, and wasn't painful.

149026594.review:
Nier Automata is a fantastic game and definitely a must play for fans of hack and slash games.

The story of Nier:Automata is excellent with some great emotional moments like [spoiler] Pascal's Village and Ending E. [/spoiler] The side quests are also great with the stand out being Emil's Memories which allows you to access t[spoiler]Emil's garden. [/spoiler]. The last ending you get is one of the most powerful emotional experiences in the game is worth the journey to get to. 

On the gameplay side of things, I really liked how the game plays with camera perspectives as well as the bullet hell sections of the game. The hack and slash part of the game is pretty good with some weapon and pod varieties but it felt a bit lacking in depth  alternative combos. There is also some customization that can be done with your equipment chips which felt fairly unique in that you can remove UI elements for some additional power.

Lastly, the soundtrack of Nier:Automata is one of the best among all the games I have played so far and really elevates the entire game to another level of quality. I really liked the Chaos language tracks of each location in the game. Some standout tracks I liked was the theme park theme and Weight of the world which plays at the end credits. 

In summary, Nier:Automata is definitely a must-play for fans of unique stories with great soundtracks.

148943426.review:
NieR is a good game. 

If using Keyboard & Mouse, the NAOIM input overhaul mod makes it a great game. This mod includes proper mouse control, a dedicated dodge button that may be binded, and just overall functionality. I had to set the third person X & Y Axis sensitivity to 3.0 using a 4k resolution.  The mod isn't perfect as some of the hacking sequences later in the game can feel a bit scuffed.


Combat is fluid and flows very well once a few plug in chips are installed. 

The game is effectively divided into 3 arcs: 2B, 9S, & 2A.   

9S's story can be tedious.  You play the same plot line again from 9S's PoV; unfortunately, this means about 1/2 the content is simply repeated.  However, the story beats unique to 9S are vital and very well done.

The third arc is all new content once you've experienced the first two arcs. 

Some of the vistas and environments are best in show. 

Music is very Ghost in the Shell and works incredibly well. I don't know who was who's inspiration, but Yoko Kanno's presence was very much felt in Keiichi Okabe's work in this game.

148907423.review:
Great Music and Visual design. Combat has some nice ideas for mechanics and story has some interesting ideas for themes, as well as potential for great characters, but nothing ever feels thought out and most of the time contradictory. Most notably: Machines and Androids are constantly described as emotionless, yet the japanese pathos cinematography makes everyone gasp in shock and awe throughout the entire game. Most egregious: the longer the game goes on, the more it tried to throw whatever deepities and pseudo-philosophical-word-salad at the wall, to see what sticks, while becoming and entirely incoherent mess, pretending to add something substantive to my mind. I read someone else critiquing this piece of media as "the writing of a teenager who just found their first look into philosophy" - a quasi "i am 14 and this is deep" - The Game - and i sadly have to agree. Overall disappointment at the potential.

Is it a "Bad Game"? I find it hard to pass a dichotomous judgement. But it's messy in almost all places and vastly overrated at ~90% positive reviews. Especially if you account that most negatives are from people complaining about technical issues.

148903045.review:
[h1]NieR:Automata Review[/h1]

First I would like to say I never played any of the other nier games or drakengard games. I know they are connected. But for my gameplay experience it didn't effect me or I didn't felt like I needed to play other games to get the context. Also I want to keep this review spoiler free as much as possible.

[h2]Story[/h2]

Story is basically you play the role of android 2B and her assigned partner 9S as humans try to take the Earth as they take shelter in Moon. Story on surface level feels really simple but the more progress in the game the more you start to see cracks on this premise. What NieR:Automata does very well is asking you philosophical questions and come to conclusions about the actions you make in the course of the game. Overall, the story was stellar and once of a lifetime experience I would say.

10/10

[h2]Setting and Environments[/h2]

NieR has an post-apocalyoptic setting which has tinge of sad but haunting beauty behind it. While some areas can feel colorful and vibrant, some areas feel a bit empty and not as interesting as the other locations. [spoiler]Looking at you desert.[/spoiler] Eventhough this is an open-world game it didn't have to be an open-world. In my opinion linear world would fit this game more because sometimes world can feel really empty like you are just going from A location to B location without anything interesting happening.

7/10

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

NieR might be a story heavy game but still shines in its combat thanks to PlatinumGames experience in this genre. Combat more revolves around weapons and chips(character upgrades basically) while different weapons offer you different playstyles while chips make you empower those builds or if you are struggling with the game help you in certain scenarios. Personally I'm not a fan of the Bullet Hell type of games and NieR has a lot of those still I throughly enjoyed it. Only criticism I can give is you have to finish the game 3 times to truly finish it. Second playthrough takes away a bit of your freedom and limits your playstyle. If you don't like the new mechanic it can be a bit dreading to play. Also eventhough second playthrough has an important part in the story it feels samey and gets boring real quick.

8/10

[h2]Graphics[/h2]

Although this game isn't groundbreaking on it's graphics I would say it looks still beautiful. And it shows you with it's environments and characters. Overall nothing gorgeous but nothing atrocious. [i]Also you can modify the graphics and models with mods to make it more beautiful[/i]

7/10

[h2]Music[/h2]

If have to summarize the NieR's music I would simply say 'hauntingly beautiful'. Keiichi Okabe's work on this game elevates most of the areas and boss fight and sometimes even taking the spotlight I would say. Making it an unforgettable experience. I still listen to it this and never get tired of it.

10/10

[h2]Overall[/h2]

NieR:Automata is a great game that I will not forget. It was an experience filled with happiness, anger and sadness. Especially the ending section. I would highly recommend.

9.5/10

[i]Personal Note: I never reviewed a game before but was compelled to it and felt like NieR had to be first. Because of this game's impact on me. So even if you don't like story heavy games I would still recommend you to try because few games can offer you this experience.[/i]

148752209.review: My first insight into the mind of Yoko Taro and the world of NieR, and I must say it's off to a good start. Some questionable structuring and gameplay decisions were made, but fortunately it was worth the (sometimes) pain of enduring though some purposedly annoying bosses and sections. Even though I began with the handicap of action RPGs not being among my favourite gaming genres, I love games like these where you start as a complete stranger to its world, and you start learning more and more about its meaning, purpose and philosophy as you progress. Playing though the game? Could've been more fun... but understading and realizing what Yoko Taro and everyone involved with the script and story wanted to convey? That's why, despite everything, I can simply not dislike this game despite its evident (in my opinion) flaws, all accompanied with a brilliant soundtrack worthy of its accolades and well-written characters, both main and secondary. Proof that games are about the experience and not about objective stats such as budget or metascore, and may even make me reconsider how I view gaming as a whole after some time.

148697773.review:
This one’s going to be a shorter review from me, since, to be honest, I wasn’t able to give this game the sort of time and attention it probably deserves. Nier: Automata is a very unique and intriguing game, with lots of great ideas, but you have to play throughout at least a couple of times to start seeing all that it has to offer. Unfortunately, there’s a huge backlog of games I’m trying to get through right now, so I’m just going to have to settle for the one playthrough. 

And that also means I’m going to eventually watch a YouTube video to understand the story. Thing is, with only one playthrough, you only get a small sliver of what’s going on. And holy hell, do I want to understand just what the hell was going on. I am left with so many questions about the story mode that I am endlessly curious about, and I wish I had the time to replay the game to have those questions answered. The small tidbits that I did experience, I absolutely loved. I think the best way to explain the story through the lens that you get is this: this game will constantly make you feel uncomfortable. Suddenly robots and the various antagonists will begin doing or carrying out sudden bouts of insanity, or something really strange will happen that you know there’s a reason for, but you just don’t know what that reason is. The imagery that some of these scenarios present will honestly stick with me forever- most notably, the return to the Factory will forever be burned in the back of my brain, and the screams of the robots yelling “WE WILL BECOME GODS” are living rent-free in my head right now. 

The gameplay is solid. It’s your typical hack-and-slash, so you’ll already know if you like that sort of thing or not. I never found any of it particularly difficult in the Normal setting. The game will often do this fun thing where it’ll change the perspective, and you’ll suddenly be playing a side-scroller or top-down hack-n-slash, which I found novel, though I would have preferred the perspective to just never change most of the time. I do love how the UI is sort of tied into some of the game’s mechanics- little things like your Memory, which is how you add on new capabilities to your character, being directly tied into whether you see your health bar or damage numbers (and there’s even Memory already being used for your OS, which is how you’re alive in the first place). Overall, the combat was nice, but nowhere near my favorite part of the game. 

The game is pretty, albeit a bit muted in its color pallet at some points. The voice acting is well done. The music does a fantastic job of setting the uncomfortable and disturbing mood at numerous points throughout the game. Although plenty of people will disagree, I am going to say that I’m not a fan of the outfit designs for a lot of characters (especially, of course, 2B). 2B felt like a very strong and interesting protagonist, but her outfit really took away from it. It just doesn’t make sense- why would they build these combat androids and have ‘em wear high heels and short frilly dresses? I don’t get it, but I know plenty of people don’t need a reason for it. 

Obviously, this game is very replayable. I believe there are four or five different “main” endings and about 20 more “extra” endings to discover. If I had the time, I would absolutely want to play again, and if you can, you absolutely should. That being said, a single playthrough is going to be a lot of fun, give you a lot of great moments, and will be well worth your time. 

I’m really glad I played Nier: Automata and got to say that I “beat” it, even though I know there’s way more that I haven't discovered. If you have the time, please give this game at least one playthrough, and I can almost guarantee you’ll want to play through it multiple times to uncover its secrets. It was a pleasure to have discovered this world and some new awesome characters like 2B and 9S, and I hope to see ‘em again one day.

148654409.review:
[NO SPOILERS]

NieR:Automata abre su telón, un juego que nos habla de la desesperación que viene ante la perdida del sentido y el sufrimiento de la vida explorando distintos temas con su impecable narrativa utilizando la Psicología y Filosofía para abordar temas como el significado del ser humano, la consciencia y la percepción de nosotros como individuos.

Los pensamientos del filosofo Friedrich Nietzsche están muy arraigados a los temas que tratan este juego, algunas preguntas como "¿Somos los humanos capaces de encontrar un sentido propio a nuestras vidas?" este pensamiento viene de la ida de "la muerte de dios" como entidad superior, anteriormente la humanidad baso su existencia y sistema morales en esta entidad que con el paso del avance del conocimiento habían racionalizado a dios como no probable desmoronando esta entidad y perdiendo el significado de la existencia debiendo de ser replanteados. Constantemente en Nier:Automata vemos a los personajes basando su existencia y sentido en una figura de autoridad o la idea de algo mayor, viendo como estas figuras van siendo destruidas y haciendo que los personajes busquen en nuevo significado a su existencia. En las maquinas también se puede encontrar esta búsqueda de sentido imitando a el comportamiento de los seres humanos para dar sentido a su existencia aun sin entender muy bien sus acciones viendo así que la vida no tiene un propósito mayor. También el juego trata el tema del eterno retorno, esta idea se basa en que la historia tiene un final y una repetición de acciones que llegan a dar una misma conclusión final repitiéndose durante los años.

La ideas de Nietzsche no son las únicas que el juego abarca, otros filósofos como Simone de Beauvoir la cual se utiliza para la creación de Simone dentro del juego compartiendo nombre y pensamientos como esta filosofa, también podemos encontrarnos una maquina con el nombre de Jean-Paul basado en el filosofo Jean-Paul Sartre, esta maquina no solo comparte el nombre si no que la forma de pensar y actuar, en el juego Simone esta enamorada de Jean-Paul que es un guiño a que Simone de Beauvoir y Jean-Paul Sartre tenían una relación. En el juego podemos ver muchos mas ejemplos como estos como: Pascal y el filosofo Blaise Pascal, el líder de la secta religiosa y el filosofo Søren Kierkegaard, el rey infante y el filosofo Immanuel Kant o la misma 2B que recibe su nombre de la famosa frase de Shakespeare "To be or not to be" estos no son nombres simplemente elegidos al azar si no que todos estos filósofos dejan su huella y sus pensamientos dentro del juego a través del personaje el cual son representados.

Para dar respuesta a todo y finalizar el juego tendremos que habernos pasado los otros 4 finales anteriores y es aquí cuando el final "E" sera presentado retomando las palabras con las que abre el juego matar a dios, en este final lucharemos contra los créditos que son los creadores del juego los dioses que crearon todo, para así acabar con esta espiral de vida y muerte, el juego nos enfrenta al mismo fracaso y desesperanza que los peonajes pero con el apoyo de otros podemos descubrir el verdadero mensaje de esta obra, la vida no tiene un significado mas haya, la muerte no es el propósito de esta existencia si no la conclusión de esta, el significado de la vida es vivir, no estamos vivos solo para morir estamos aquí disfrutar de este enrevesado rompecabezas que llamamos vida, así Nier:Automata cierra su telón.

148581552.review:
I'll start by saying this is a good game, but I have no idea why some people act like it is the pinnacle of society. The strongest part of this game is the story, which I will admit is cool and is probably the major reason I was able to complete all of the "core" endings. That being said, however, the story has its issues and like before, I can't understand why so many think it is comparable to the greatest literary works in our world. I'll even go so far to say that if you haven't played at least Replicant, half the story will have very little impact on you and you'll probably actually dislike it. I also believe that the story doesn't really pick up and get "decent" until the 3rd ending, and it doesn't get "good" until the last ending.

The combat has a lot of potential but it isn't realized that well. There are a bunch of weapons, different combos, pods, chips, and upgrades. This is all well and good, until you recognize that all of that is pointless because the enemies are bland and repetitive. They barely react when you hit them (if it wasn't a 1 shot), and increasing difficulty just makes the fight take longer because the enemies now have 5 times the health, with no new AI or movesets. Upping the difficulty also increases enemy damage to a ridiculous amount and until you have leveled up and gotten some good chips, everything will 1-2 shot you. The difficulty scaling in this game in general is weird to me. Easy is pretty much just watching cutscenes with some button mashing in-between when you have to fight something. Normal is still just watching cutscenes with some button mashing in-between when you have to fight something. Hard jumps into unfair territory where you either pay in the most boring way possible to stay alive, or you are dead.

Although I said the story is good, a lot of the characters involved are pretty bland. I know it was a design decision to make them like this, but it wasn't a good choice in my opinion. Many people will say there is a lot of character growth in this game, and I would like to disagree heavily. A great deal of the "character development" for Automata is established outside of this game in side material like the books/manga. The game itself hardly contains any of this context, so we are left with a lot of dry performances between characters that have no personality or chemistry.

Following tradition from Replicant/Gestalt, the side quests are absolutely tedious and horrible. If I wanted to do fetch quests I would play an MMO. There are some gems hidden in the heap of trash, but good lord was it not worth the trouble sifting to find them.

This all leads up to my biggest gripe with the game: rail shooter sections. I understand the desire this series has to change genres rapidly, but holy hell why are there rail shooter segments? Not only why are they there, WHY ARE THERE SO MANY OF THEM? Who likes these? I almost stopped playing every time one of these pop up, including right at the very beginning of the game.

TLDR and my major takeaway: When they are on sale, pick up Nier Replicant and Automata. Play through all of Replicant's endings (better game IMO), and then try to get to ending E in Automata. These are good games and while they have issues I think they are worth a playthrough if you snag them on sale.

148569880.review:
TL;DR: One of the most unforgettable experiences in all of gaming, a must-play for anyone who considers themselves a fan of the artistic medium that is videogames. [b]S[/b].

NieR:Automata is my favorite game of all time. I'll admit it, I really love this game. It's been I think a year or maybe two since I first played it and my feelings have barely changed. 

The gameplay is very reminiscent of the character action game genre, albeit it is also an RPG. The open world is there, but it isn't really a selling point as there's very little to do in it. Level design is on point at basically all times, even when levels are reused on subsequent routes. It's not too long either, even if you plan on achieving all of the game's major endings. There are a few points in the game where it is a little too difficult or too easy, at least on normal mode, but it never overstays its welcome. The hard mode's balancing is ridiculous and I don't really find it rewarding to play whatsoever, even though normal mode can get a bit easy near the end of the game. Overall, 9/10 in gameplay, it could be better but not by much.

The story is... excellent. I'd rather not spoil anything, but its a game that you will think about for years after playing it and the story is the reason why. 5/5.

The art is good, even by modern standards for a game that's already 5 years old. In a few places it isn't ideal, and the character designs are... a bit much at times, but there's a reason why 2B is one of the most iconic characters in modern gaming. 4.5/5, it has already aged very well.

They came up with an entire new language for the music, completely unnecessary and just a massive flex, but I'll respect it. 5/5, fantastic, some highlights are the first route's final boss theme and the end credits, as well as the title menu. Weight of the World is one of my favorite songs just period, and even though I prefer the Japanese version, which I don't believe is present in the English release, it's still fantastic.

147988405.review:
I had very high hopes for Nier Automata due to the high praise it was getting from everyone and it still managed to beat my expectations. As someone who doesn't usually play JRPGs I must say it felt a bit weird at first but I gradually got the hang of it.
 
[NO SPOILERS]

Nier Automata is probably the most gripping game I have ever played. Everything felt so well crafted from its Incredibly beautiful and tragic story to its heavenly music, along with likeable characters and a beautiful world. The game also focuses on some though provoking topics like philosophy, existentialism, literature.

The game has 26 "endings" named from A-Z. The main story takes about 35 hr. to complete and takes you through endings A,B,C,D,E. All other endings are basically "joke" endings which are pretty easy to achieve (except ending Y). Reaching to ending Y takes a lot of grinding and took me nearly 80 hr. to achieve.

From a technical point of view, the game ran smoothly without any issues. It is probably better to use a controller but I played with mouse and keyboard and faced no issues.

This was a once in a lifetime experience I wish I could experience like the first time.

147797298.review:
It is truly a shame that this game was kept in its poor launch state on PC for over four years. I can imagine many tried it, only to not get far because the port was just that sloppy. It was thankfully fixed in 2021, and I am personally very grateful for that because I very well might not have ever given it a chance otherwise.

Nier Automata is a part of Yoko Taro's Drakengard series, however it is so far disconnected from the trilogy that actually bears that name, and even the first Nier game (Nier Replicant), that it is a game that can be perfectly enjoyed on its own without any understanding of what came before it. Yes, Nier Replicant does kind of build the foundation for the world that you experience in Automata, but because Automata takes place so long after Replicant it isn't necessary to know the history of the world explained in the first game to enjoy the events of the sequel.

What makes this game so special is how incredibly unique it is. You simply experience stuff you've never seen in any other game before, and it all works very well to enhance the gameplay and storytelling. Nier Automata's story was truly made to be told in video game form. Also, I do have to mention the music: it is simply incredible.

Whatever negatives I can think of for this game are so minor compared to the overall awesome experience that they are not really worth elaborating on beyond a brief mention: side quests are generally not that interesting apart from a handful, combat is not very deep, and the visuals certainly are not terribly impressive even for 2017 standards. That really is, however, about all I can think of for my gripes with this game.

Goated game. Please play it.

to be able to save the game you have to finish the prologue. what the game doesnt tell you is that it takes 45+ minutes to finish the prologue, which is a boring repetitive mess and a slog, plus win 2 boss fights, and if you die during the boss fight you have to start the entire process over again. this is a terrible design that one could argue is made to keep people from being able to refund the game by going over the 2 hour limit.

i dont have the time or patience to spend 45 minutes boring myself, just to retry a boss and be able to move on in the game, the rest of the game and story be damned.

not to mention, as is tradition with most japanese made games, the game is hard locked to 60fps and some animations and cutscenes are tied to the games frame rate, meaning modding the game to go above 60fps breaks the game.

After originally giving up on my first playthrough of this game a year back, I decided to revisit it, and oh boy was it worth it.

The world is full of mystery, the characters are all interesting and well voiced and the music is absolutely amazing. The game's soundtrack is one of the best I've ever heard. Just exploring the world with it makes the game a lot more enjoyable than it would be otherwise.

The story is told through multiple playthroughs in which different perspectives are shown and parts of the story are better explained.

The themes in Nier:Automata are also very thought provoking and makes you really wonder about life.

All in all, I would highly recommend this game to anyone who's willing to play it.

146775497.review: The three main areas: city, forest, and desert are beautiful and alive with characters. The weakest point of the game is the camera, but it is not a big enough issue to harp on; sometimes when it zooms in or out too far it makes seeing your surroundings and enemies difficult, but it isn't a game breaker. Overall it is pretty short if you stick to the main quest, but it offers replayability in unlocking the other endings (which I almost certainly won't do).

146690065.review:
So, this is going to be a interesting review since i haven't done one in a good while after my Alan Wake review, but a lot's kinda happened so i haven't been able to do one yet, most of it's personal stuff I don't really want to get into, but before I start reviewing, I might as well state the reason why I got this game, two reasons why is because that first, I recently preordered Alan Wake 2, and that doesn't come out until later in October and second, because after I finished Death Stranding, my uncle recommended me to play this game, so after a few months, I did, and this is the result, as usual, Sections for Story, Music, and gameplay, and this time, World, trust me.

Story: The story is actually really good, like specifically, when it comes to characters, you can really get attached to them, like say Pascal, the machine is a lovable character and just wants peace [spoiler]until the village gets attacked later in the story[/spoiler] and from what i've seen, the lore apparently way more deeper then I realized, not as much as say Destiny per say, but it's still deep, so I encourage you to check the lore in your spare time, it's complex as hell but interesting, oh, and let's not forget about how you progress the story, specifically, if you want to finish the game, you gotta beat it at least 3 times to get the full story, and how it does it, well, reminds me a lot of MGSV actually, because when you go through each playthrough, it feels like a free built in DLC that expands the story, where this game feels like it has something MGSV doesn't really have: Chapter segements.

Music: Beautiful and really good, It fits the world really well, and really dramatic, not much I can say here really, just loved the music because Weight of the World kinda made me cry after i finished playing

Gameplay: Loved it, It has the same feel as say DMC, oh and Pods are your best friend so try and use them when you can, and hell, even the sidequests themselves feel fun aswell, kinda shocking i know, but it's a first for everything, and when you die in game, the game will keep your corpse until you come back and collect it, which is pretty helpful despite this game not being a souls-like

World: Best way I can describe it is that it's like a Ghibli film but darker and philosophical then Grave of the Fireflies, but also very peaceful (if you ignore the killer machines), and just that when you walk around the world, you can't help but feel, well, kinda sad for some reason, at least, that's how it felt for me.

Final Thoughts: Nier Automata is a game that has managed to make me cry after playing the game, and I personally think that's saying something, I love the story, personal favorite, and IS in the same level as Death Stranding in my opinion, and has themes in it that remind me of Everything Everywhere all at Once, the final thoughts are short because i realize that most of what I wanted to say didn't need to be censored, Honestly, doing this i thought I had to censor most of the story segment, but I didn't need to and only censored one part of it, which is...actually, you just have to see it in game to see what I mean, so, in other words, keep on keeping on for the glory to mankind.

146503420.review:
I am a bit mixed on this since it started so high. But it sure ended low. I'll explain without spoiling. Game completed entirely on Normal difficulty. The tie breaker between good and bad was broken by technical problems.

-The Bad-
*Anything to do with the mini-game which is unlocked later in the game. It overstays its welcome by several magnitudes and becomes such a detriment that it actively sucks the fun out of the game. It breaks the flow of the game a lot. There is no way to alter the core gameplay through chips or weapons like everything else in the game. The first time will be the same as the last. What starts off as a novel and interesting idea for a game within a game, it is quickly shown to be shallow and repetitive. It's not bad. There is just way too much of it. You are warned. If you buy this game, by the time you know what this is it's too late.

*I had this game crash 4 times total. 3 of those were at the final ending for the main story. Coupled with my frustrations at the mini-game sections, it totally robbed me of the joy of seeing the proper ending. Great port, SE. Well done. I also ran into what is known as the "white screen of death". It is a white screen only but button inputs still seem to work. I mashed buttons and got out of it somehow but it's still noteworthy.

-The Good-
*This game has a really fun combat system with several weapons that pair together in different move-sets. You can have a variety of attacks to dispatch your foes. There are also many ways to customize your characters through various chips. [i]Edit: This has a very big and obvious caveat that ties into the first main "bad" point I made.[/i]

*There are many side quests that take you to all parts of the game's world.

*Most of the characters are likable.

*A very unique and interesting approach to story-telling and camera work.

*Incredible OST.

The game is fine. I loved some aspects and not others. A literal mixed bag for me. However, it's entirely serviceable but I'm not sure I'll be revisiting this any time in the near future.

146303407.review:
[h3][b]Keep in mind that the ultimate conclusion cyclically aligns with the initial outset.[/b][/h3]

[b]NieR: Automata[/b] stands as a profoundly intellectually stimulating and emotionally immersive opus. The intricacy of its narrative is imbued with finesse, with each facet of its structurally delineated artistry showcasing uniquely exquisite conceptualizations. This aesthetic allure unfolds in multifarious layers, masterfully interwoven.

The underlying philosophy coursing through NieR: Automata delves into profound existential and nihilistic inquiries, offering an intriguing opportunity to illuminate the labyrinthine tapestry of meanings woven within its narrative and philosophical framework.

[b]"[/b][i]Everything that lives is designed to end. We are perpetually trapped in a never-ending spiral of life and death. Is this a curse? Or some kind of punishment? I often think about the god who blessed us with this cryptic puzzle, and wonder if we'll ever get the chance to kill him.[/i][b]"[/b]

Friedrich Nietzsche, the herald of the trenchant aphorism "God is dead," expounded upon the metamorphosis of morality and beliefs in the modern epoch. Within Nietzschean philosophy, this aphorism signifies the gradual erosion of traditional religious convictions, giving rise to a metaphysical void. As contemporary society distances itself from theological conceptions wherein God is the fount of meaning and values, an existential abyss and tormented existence emerge. In Nietzsche's "Thus Spoke Zarathustra," composed in 1883, the intricacy of the "eternal return" concept is meticulously explored. It posits that in an infinite and cyclical cosmos, every event, past, present, or future, inexorably repeats, bearing profound existential implications. The protagonist, Zarathustra, confronts the vision of eternal recurrence, initially overwhelmed by the weight of an existence perpetually echoing itself. Nevertheless, as the narrative unfolds, Zarathustra transcends this nihilistic perspective, embracing the notion as a challenge to live authentically and forge one's own purpose amidst the repetition of existence.

[b]"[/b][i]Everything that lives is designed to end. They are perpetually trapped in a never-ending spiral of life and death. However, life is all about the struggle within this cycle. That is what 'we' believe.[/i][b]"[/b]

The contemplation of death lies at the heart of profound ontological inquiries within philosophical currents. Death, the most somber inevitability in human existence, bestows upon us the poignant capacity for reflection. The absurdity encapsulating death may not represent the initial definition of death proffered in Jean-Paul Sartre's 1943 magnum opus, "Being and Nothingness," but it serves to underscore its logical primacy within Sartre's oeuvre. Sartre's conception of the absurdity of death embarks on a philosophical voyage, unfurling into a nuanced examination of the human condition confronted with its inexorable and inescapable terminus. For Sartre, death ascends to the zenith of absurdity because, despite our Herculean efforts to ascribe meaning to life, death remains the immutable event that terminates all our achievements and aspirations. It represents the ultimate and insurmountable divide that renders ephemeral our endeavors and struggles. Thus, the existential paradox is evident: despite our freedom to elect our values and purposes in life, death serves as an unyielding constraint, causing all semblance of meaning to dissipate in the face of finite existence. This dialectic between freedom and death begets profound anguish; even as we consciously select our actions and values, we are eternally confronted with the inevitability of ultimate annihilation. Hence, death, in Sartre's worldview, emerges as a pivotal element of human existence, not solely as life's conclusion but as an incessant reminder of the transitory nature of our endeavors. It stands as a mirror reflecting our ceaseless struggle to unearth meaning and purpose, even when confronted with the void of inherent significance.

[b]"[/b][i]A future is not given to you. It is something you must take for yourself.[/i][b]"[/b]

In the work "Existentialism is a Humanism," penned by Jean-Paul Sartre in 1946, a cogent apologia for existentialism is enunciated, championing the primacy of human existence over essence. Sartre underscores that human beings are fundamentally endowed with freedom, thrust into the world devoid of preordained purpose, thereby bearing the responsibility to craft their own meaning and values. Existence, he contends, precedes essence, and within this radical liberty resides the agonizing, yet transformative potential for each individual to mold their own destiny and genuinely embrace their human condition. The cosmos' void endows us with a unique quest to construct our essence.

The musical tapestry of NieR: Automata unfurls as a sublime labyrinth of harmonies, resonating within the very core of the game, surpassing the boundaries of mere convention.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7jna9bvhdRE

The painstakingly crafted score by Keiichi Okabe materializes as a symphony of emotions, akin to rivers of consciousness navigating the tumultuous waters of hope and desolation. Each musical composition stands as a sonorous poem, rich in subtleties and hues that beckon profound, uncharted contemplations. The vocals, often ethereal in nature, transport us to an ethereal realm of human expression where words falter, and melodies assume the role of tacit narrators, revealing the depths of the characters' souls. The interplay of diverse musical genres, from classical to electronic, forges a sonic mosaic that reverberates with the intricacies embodied in every facet of this masterpiece. This musical arrangement is more than a mere backdrop; it is the very protagonist of the narrative. The music does not merely accompany; it converses, divulging secrets, voicing anguish, and echoing the profound existential questions permeating the narrative. Of particular intrigue is the unique lexicon employed within these melodies. The "Chaos Language," conceived by composer Keiichi Okabe, materializes as an abstract tongue, devoid of recognizable semantics or syntax. Instead, it comprises vocal sounds that conjure emotions yearning for expression. The incorporation of such an exquisite language into the vocal compositions within the score engenders a sense of both peculiarity and familiarity, echoing the theme of communication and comprehension among disparate beings, whether human, android, or machine. This concept finds eloquent expression through this medium.

This endeavor to elucidate select facets of artistic expression within a video game, albeit a modest one, scarcely captures the magnificence of this universe and its interpretation within the crucible of human cognition. Nonetheless, this endeavor remains rooted in the pursuit of expression. In the end, [b]do you think video games are silly little things?[/b]

146268191.review:
"Do you think games are silly little things"
-Yoko Taro
Have you ever questioned what games are and what they can be?
This is the best game to release in 2017, arguably the best game to come out this decade, and in my opinion possibly the best game I have ever played. People look at Zelda or Mario 64 and see them as games--while not perfect, as games that managed to set the standard and define what great games can achieve in the late 90's to today. Nier Automata is the game that will define both story telling and gameplay from 2017 and beyond.

NieR:Automata defies expectations in both story and gameplay, combining them in ways I personally never thought to be possible. This is done by either straight up changing the genre of the game, hitting you with a heart-compelling character interaction, or a combination of both. The game plays the way you want it to. If you are feeling like it's too easy after setting it to hard mode you can remove HUD elements, increase damage taken, or dive into the combat system and learn 15+ weapon combos by combining your 4 equipped weapons and your pod. The game is meant to have you experience it the way YOU want to. If the game is too hard you can equip as many chips as possible and set the game to easy, basically having the game play itself by healing and fighting for you so you can experience the story the way YOU wish to.

In order to experince Nier:Automata fully, the game is designed to be played multiple times. After initially beating the game, you replay the game from another perspective. After that, the game opens up even more in a way you wouldn't ever see coming in a blind playthrough, opening the world up even more (quite literally). This idea of story telling may throw people off initially but can only truly be accomplished in this form of medium--as a game.

I never really saw video games as an art. Video Games have defining artstyles, music, atmosphere, themes, and so on...yet I never considered them as an artform, just something that is there to entertain me. NieR:Automata showed me the light. The atmosphere is truly something else. When it wants to, Nier makes you feel part of it's universe, and then a moment later you are catching your breath and you feel something off. You then remember that you are playing a video game. This is done intentionally and happened to me multiple times. As someone who enjoys phycological elements in entertainment, while questioning the motives of characters and diving into the meaning of character interactions, cutscenes, and atmosphere, I ended up questioning what I was doing as a player experiencing Nier:Automata.

As I was questioning myself, I was also wondering what made me want to question myself as a player. I have no idea how to describe that feeling other as looking into your heart. NieR:Automata is a game meant entertain your heart and make you feel something. It will likely be different for you, but I ended up feeling something amazing inside me up until the end of the game and past the credits.

And this feeling is something I wish for you, a potential player, to pick up and experience yourself.
Please play this game.
Even if my words are meaningless
I will sacrifice anything and everything if it helps even one person complete it, like I'm carrying the weight of the world.
-Planter

146121891.review:
=== STORY ===
Thousands of years into the future, aliens have invaded Earth, using machine lifeforms as their army, forcing humanity to flee to the Moon.  Here, they regroup and counter-attack by creating the YoRHa, a military force of advanced androids with the mission of eliminating the invading force and reclaim Earth for humanity. In this virtually never ending conflict, the story follows 2B and 9S, a couple of YoRHa androids as they travel to Earth to complete missions and also learn about the world that is and was,, themselves as well about their supposed enemies. 

A little side-note: despite being related to the Drakengard series and Nier: Replicant, you don’t need to have played or know about these games before playing Automata. It could help you understand a bit more some details in the game but in general, Automata is like its own story, son don’t worry about that.


=== GAMEPLAY ===
The game is a mix of action-RPG with Open World. 
Combat is your standard hack and slash; light and heavy attacks, jump, run as well special attacks. Stats automatically upgrade as you level up.

Special attacks and weapons can be unlock/upgraded by completing mini-quests (collect certain amount and type of materials and money) or finding them during you gameplay (around certain area, quest reward, bought on store). There’s a ton of options/variants to choose from but most of them aren’t too distinctive one from another (especially when it comes to weapons) and in the end, you’ll end up using just a few from all that bunch.
Combat in general is nice but it can get kinda repetitive after a while.
When it comes to the Open World part, the game offers a fairly decent map to explore around. You start in a main area that connects to the rest of the other areas, which you gain access as you progress in the game. Each of these areas have its own “theme” sort of speak and does a good enough work to represent them, some more than others though.

The RPG element comes in the form of chips. These chips are divided according their function (attack, defense, support, etc.) and can help you create a build for your standard gameplay or for specific scenarios and even personalize your UI to some extent. You have “memory space” which you can fill with these with each one using an X amount of space, depending their level (you can upgrade them) and/or rarity. You can upgrade the memory space later in the game.


=== VISUALS & SOUND ===
I think this is some of the strong elements of this game.

On the visual side, you can see they put a lot of work on each aspect of the game: the characters (especially the characters), weapons, environments, menus, etc. It’s pretty cool to appreciate the details in each one. You can kinda have an idea of the character traits of each character when you look at it and their designs, same of the weapons (even the weapons have backstories so its look is not necessarily just because).

About the music, the OST does a great job on help you immerse in the game. The fights, the story, dialogues, even the side-quests, the OST has the right theme to go along with the “current mood” in the game. It hardly fails in this and I appreciate that <3. I haven’t heard the OST alone yet but I can bet it must be awesome to hear it while imagine the scenes in the game.     

  
=== FINAL THOUGHTS ===
Leaving aside the gameplay and visual/sound aspects for a moment, I think the core of this game are the characters and how the interact, learn, grow, get emotional, etc. and not just the protagonists; the support/side-characters, even most of the NPCs you’ll probably know once are pretty interesting!  The gameplay is just a drive sort of speak to help you navigate in this broken world full of interesting characters waiting to be discovered. Interaction is the key word in this game and…is just a fascinating experience.
The gameplay is good, visuals and sounds are pretty good but the story and characters will stick to you from start to finish. I think this a game everyone should try, at least once.


SCORE: 8.0

This is the perfect blend of action RPG and Shoot-em up. 
The combat is satisfying.
The side quests are interesting and none of them felt like fillers.
There is no need for grinding.
There is a New Game + mode that is almost a must because it brings so much variety. One could even argue that the game really starts on your third play-through.
There is even an easy-mode in which not only are the enemies easier, but the game takes all the hassle away (auto-fire, auto-item, auto-build, and more) if you need it.

The story is typical Japanese crap. It's meant to be more atmospheric then sensical. The main tone is melancholy.

145968960.review: Agggg el maggg, la primera vez que comencé este juego solo vine por 2B y listo, luego llegué hasta cierto punto de la historia y creía que era todo ya que lo jugué con bastante prisa. Ahora nuevamente lo vuelvo a jugar en PC desde 0 completando cada historia secundaria y vamos, es una joya en toda la extensión de la palabra; Misiones secundarias, trama principal, BANDA SONORAAA kyaaa. Bueno, me queda por agregar que el juego claramente no te miente cuando dice que debes volver a jugarlo al terminarlo por primera vez, pues en la segunda run vas a entender muuuuchas cosas que tienen un trasfondo bien oscuro :'c. Sé curioso, se gentil y sé cuidadoso con tus decisiones, tendrás oportunidad de corregirlas en un futuro pero es mejor hacerlo bien a la primera :3, ahora me toca esperar a que pongan el Replicant en descuento para poder jugarlo x'd

145959124.review: Una obra maestra, a todo aquel que quiera jugar este juego, le recomiendo ampliamente que busque sacar todos los finales posibles, es algo en lo que no se tienen que rendir aunque algunos sean bastante difíciles de conseguir.

145949168.review: NieR: Automata, cautiva con su narrativa profunda y personajes conmovedores. Ambientado en un mundo post-apocalíptico, donde sigues a los androides 2B y 9S  en una guerra contra máquinas, explorando temas de conciencia y humanidad. Con mecánicas de combate fluidas y una impresionante dirección artística, ofrece una experiencia única e inolvidable. Su alta jugabilidad y múltiples finales garantizan una inmersión duradera en esta obra maestra de los videojuegos.

Es un juego excelente y de los pocos que realmente me motivaron a sacar el platino.

en cuanto a la jugabilidad es bastante divertida aunque los niveles son muy cuesta arriba en la primera run asi que no sean como yo y guarden las secundarias del maestro servo para 9s yo soy el unico loco que se hizo esa madre entera con 2B xd
y por ultimo la historia es increíble.
PD: deberian darle un buen aumento al que diseño a 2B ese man consiguió la perfección vivan esa nalgas con mas polígonos que el ocarina.

145899341.review:
"Glory to Mankind!"

I can't believe such a beautiful and deep story can be made with androids/machines as your main characters. Excellent story, beautifully deep music tracks and such well-written characters. 

This game really makes you think about concepts such as nihilism, fate, etc.

Also, it might not be very clear, so please don't stop after finishing your 1st playthrough. This game has 5 main endings achieved through 3 playthroughs. And all of those playthroughs are completely different. The real story is gradually unfolded across these 3 playthroughs, so just stopping at the first playthrough will leave you with an incomplete game experience. 

Hope everyone has as much fun, and more, as I did playing this masterpiece.

145854291.review: Came for the thighs, stayed for the game, leaved with existential crisis

145845117.review:
[h1]Straw man the game ™,[/h1]

Genuinely the most overrated story I've ever experienced. It's literally the "I drew myself as the gigachad and you as the sojak so I win" of video games. Non organic life can be conscious because we wrote them to be that way (while offering no explanation as to why that would be the case). We will conveniently act as if there has never been a belief system that lasted since the begging of humanity and is currently going strong because that would ruin our reddit philosophy game. And of course we will offer our own solution even though we can't do that in good faith if we play by our own rules. I absolutely regret going into both Nier games expecting anything meaningful and thought provoking. Ended up being a grand waste of time.

[h2]It wasn't all bad though.[/h2]
While the progression system was just as much of a joke as the story, I have to applaud the music, art direction and boss sequences as much as possible. There were some truly jaw dropping spectacle moments. There is pure gold in Nier Automata, but I can't in good faith give it a positive review when it has such a delusional disingenuous story. 

[h1]FRAUDULENT[/h1]

145569261.review:
If steam had an option for a neutral review, I'd probably use that feature for this game.

NieR:Automata is a game I respect because it's quite unique, but I must be honest. I enjoyed very little of the experience, save for the credits of the last ending, which is more for novelty than anything else. Story was a huge disappointment for me, which is an issue when it's the main selling point of the game. It's occasionally interesting, but lacks any real substance. For a game that's supposed to be deeply philosophical, most of the interesting topics aren't addressed much. The first playthough was actually pretty interesting story wise, but the second is not nearly different enough and the third is too edgy for my tastes. Combat is very brainless and is pretty disappointing considering other work Platinum has done. I had to really push through for the true ending, and while it's the best part of the game I don't think it was worth forcing myself through 20 hours of mind numbing gameplay. The only aspect of this game that met expectations was the OST, which is certainly very good (though I wouldn't say it's the best). I don't regret the purchase, but I do wish I enjoyed the experience more, and I can't in good faith recommend it.
