145448964.review:
**Disclaimer: I played through 'Automata' twice (offline-mode) and have a 40 hours save file and a 90 hours almost 100% file (except for a tutorial entry - yes! - and a swordfish machine.**

'Automata' is a great game, and you don't need me to tell you this. But I feel somewhat obligated to write a review since I had such harsh words for the atrocious 'Nier: Replicant'.
There were three games at the end of the last decade that set new standards for interactive story-telling: 'Detroit: Become Human', 'Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice' and 'Nier: Automata'. The first and the last are similar in thematic scope and impact, dealing with the implications of independent A.I. and the question of them becoming sentient. 'Hellblade' is a devastating game about psychosis and auto-aggression.
All three are essential entries in the videogame library, recommended for almost any player, and well worth at full price. Some deliberate limitations in exploration and gameplay mechanics cut 'Nier Automata's achievements a little bit short. The greatest flaws are plot points which are sloppy and contrived as well as a fundamental misunderstanding of the concept of tragedy. The story and its greater background are rather a series of calamities, nothing more and nothing less. Thus, 'Automata' does neither reach the emotional depth of 'Hellblade' (88/100) nor accomplish the relentlessness and replayability of 'Detroit: Become Human' (90/100). My final verdict is a very solid 86/100, a must-play with some regrettable and also unnecessary flaws.

For those still reading I'll break down the major points I have to make.
**Spoiler alert from here on!**

PRO
- 2B is the main attraction here, fantastic character design
- characters (A2, pods, Jackass etc.), story and world design; cool cyberpunk approach
- post-post-apocalyptic inclinations: machines are at war while their respective creators have perished long ago
- fun ending mechanics, except maybe for path B
- good enemy variety
- money is earned easily and the leveling mechanics is actually quite good
- fast-travel system
- cool 'Shin Godzilla' easter egg

CON
- 9S is a cliché character, the curious young man setting out to explore the world - he is basically 2B's younger brother, his flirting with her and the operators is weird
- 9S's maniac obsession and him becoming insane does not work, but rather give way to some cringe
- tired and unconvincing revenge plot (branches C and D), degenerating basically into a man on a quest to avenge his woman - how troped can you get?
- 2B isn't really the protagonist, the biggest mistake is the game getting rid of her too soon, take a note: never get rid of the girl, that's what made 'Chamber of Secrets' so terrible
- allusions to the Drakengard/Nier background lore are way too cryptic
- Adam and Eve are great when introduced, only to be finished off really quickly
- many situations with A2 are contrived: her killing the forest king, 9S just arriving seconds too late, miscommunication or deliberate withdrawal of vital information between A2 and 9S
- many unresolved questions: Why *are* machines imitating aspects of human culture? Why did A2 kill Immanuel, the infant forest king? (This required intel and infiltration. If she just wanted to destroy machines, why come here?) What did Adam want to accomplish by being killed - did his curiosity override his programming?
- bad port: technical issues galore, somewhat remedied by the patch they gave us 4 (read: four, and in words: four) years after release
- insanely bad controls in the PC port: hacking is an unplayable chore, and you can still not use debug mode with keyboard/mouse - what the heck?
- annoying camera design in some places, especially the 2D-portions
- jump mechanics are deliberately limited, making it quite difficult to reach certain spots, this just intensifies the grind
- annoying 'stumble' mechanics breaking your speed movement
- controlling machine lifeforms becomes an irritating chore
- much unnecessary grind, there is a bunch of rare events improbable to achieve ever (e.g. tutorials at 85% after 70 hours, are you kidding me?)
- side quests reset between branches
- lame DLC arenas

Final words (interpretation). The main points of the game are: (1) Machines imitate human life - even the alien machines, that is - although it has no meaning for them. (2) Machines emulating human culture and human emotions is the only thing that will ultimately be left of humanity. (3)  Existence is an endless, self-sufficient war without purpose and without a goal. (4) Violence is wrong and, more importantly, un-heroic. (5) Basic activities in life are pointless, they are just chores. Conclusion: What more can you wish for when it comes to making a game experience that really makes you think?

145401274.review: There are some interesting storytelling moments and meta-interactions that take full advantage of video games as a medium that I've never seen in any other game and truly push the form forward, and I really wish they made up more of the game. Unfortunately they're surrounded by hours and hours and hours of boring and predictable slog including replaying the entire first campaign with maybe 20 minutes of actual meaningful additional content just to get to the true final campaign which itself is only a few more hours of actual content. The hack and slash gameplay is solid but not complex or varied enough to stay interesting for the whole runtime, and the I'm 14 And This Is Deep plot doesn't make up for the just ok action. It's obvious within 10 minutes of starting the game that it's about "What if robots became sentient, and what's the difference between AI and Human Intelligence?" but the game has absolutely nothing interesting to say about these cliches because 20 hours into the game even though you regularly interact with an entire society of sentient robots the main characters still refuse to admit robots can be sentient, despite themselves being sentient "androids" which is totally a huge difference! The game's "twist" that Androids and Machines both have the same AI is comically transparent and unimpactful, and Bladerunner had more to say about the trope of an android questioning its own humanity 40 years ago in an hour and a half movie than Nier does in 45 hours of game plus tons and tons of shallow text logs. The weird and off-putting anime holdovers like the main character's cringe loli outfit make the shallow philosophy seem even more unserious, and add to the feeling that this game is mainly targeted at 17 year old weeb stoners

The game suffers from some of the same outdated design elements as so many other Japanese games, unfortunately. Some examples: Not allowing you to save unless you are in a specific location, deactivating fast travel destinations seemingly just to inconvenience you, making you replay long sections you've already mastered if you ever die (which fortunately won't happen often), a barely usable map which will lead to you looking up a quest location online at least once (mark my words), and of course the player character for no particular reason running around basically butt naked.

[h3] This game is an optimization of the previous work in many aspects, including the improvement of the writer's wicked sense of humor. [/h3]
Game: The characters no longer walk stiffly, but there are also some erotic elements. The plot has been complemented a lot, but the save file is still the same old routine. When setting up the battle chip, the game may crash, and the disgusting save mechanism will return your save file directly to the morning, wasting hours of gameplay. The map is also a problem. Sometimes there are no things in the area, but there are small red dots. There are too many air walls on the map, which may cause players to lose their way.
There is no particularly profound discussion in this generation's plot, at least I don't think there is as profound as the previous generation. I have always wanted to say that if you want to create a work that discusses human nature, especially in the robot genre, you must learn to program yourself and understand the difference between a program and a person. You can't just write a person and put a robot's shell on it to tell a morality that people praise.
I didn't see the concept of "transformation", I only saw the setting, which disappointed me about this game.

145208224.review:
NieR: Automata™ is a masterpiece. It is a game that is both visually stunning and emotionally resonant, with a story that will stay with you long after you finish playing. The gameplay is also top-notch, combining fast-paced action with a deep and rewarding RPG system.

The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity has been driven off Earth by an alien invasion. The only survivors are a group of androids who have been sent to reclaim the planet. You play as 2B, a combat android who is tasked with destroying the machines that have taken over Earth.

The story is one of the game's strongest points. It is complex and thought-provoking, and it explores themes of identity, purpose, and what it means to be human. The characters are also well-developed and relatable, and you will find yourself rooting for them throughout the game.

The gameplay is a lot of fun. It is a mix of hack-and-slash action and third-person shooting, and it is fast-paced and exciting. You can also hack into machines to control them, which adds an extra layer of strategy to the combat.

The game is also visually stunning. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the character designs are unique and memorable. The soundtrack is also excellent, and it perfectly complements the game's atmosphere.

Overall, NieR: Automata™ is an outstanding game that is sure to leave a lasting impression. It is a must-play for anyone who enjoys action RPGs, thought-provoking stories, or simply beautiful games.

Here are some specific compliments I have for the game:

- The story is incredibly well-written and thought-provoking. It explores complex themes of identity, purpose, and what it means to be human in a way that is both engaging and thought-provoking.
- The characters are well-developed and relatable. You will find yourself rooting for them throughout the game.
- The gameplay is a lot of fun. It is fast-paced, exciting, and strategic.
- The graphics are stunning. The environments are beautifully rendered, and the character designs are unique and memorable.
- The soundtrack is excellent. It perfectly complements the game's atmosphere.

I hope this review has convinced you to check out NieR: Automata™. It is a truly special game that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

145107680.review: A masterpiece that may never get to experience again, yet it aims toward constructing a meaning in a world where hope is in actuality buried. It's not just some silly little game, it's a compelling narrative told in a distinctive style that fills in all the blanks as you get to know the characters and story. I never played a game by the creator, so everything was so odd in the beginning, but that obliviousness added unique touch of flavor that resonated with me at the end. The game's great storyline forces the player to consider their ideas and behavior. Teaches the player that there are various points of view and decisions that have implications rather than an objective truth or morality. Demonstrates to the user that life is not defined by a single aim or objective but rather by the experiences and connections made along the road. In a brutal and chaotic world, the game invites the user to discover their own purpose and value. There are many references to human culture, behavior, nature, and philosophies. The characters reference it either explicit or implicit from the perspective of not having lived in the modern human world, but in an post-apocalyptic world where our traditions seem absurd to them; reminding us to elicit gratitude of things we gotten used to. One of my favorite philosophical notions from the game is that according to Jean-Paul Sarte, "Existence precedes essences," meaning that a person's existence is shaped by their experiences and choices rather than being predetermined at birth. I believe in the universal scale, that everything is balanced in all aspects of reality, and that there is a certain amount of randomness that imparts some significance to our mere existence and suggests that our lives are not entirely predetermined. Our self-awareness gives the capacity for decision-making, which I like to refer to as constrained free will, allowing us to experience to degree of free-will. This is because experiencing is the ultimate objective of living things, which was likely foretold and deliberately carried out by higher sentient entities (god/gods) for what appears to be like an eternal of us. Holy cow i didn't mean to ramble on like this, i don't wanna go too deep into it;ANYWAYS! The game's outstanding visual and auditory experience completely immerse the player in its world and feelings. Beautiful visuals, fluid fighting, and a variety of gameplay elements keep the player interested and entertained in this game. The game also includes a fantastic soundtrack that perfectly matches the atmosphere and tone of the game. The music in the game is dynamic and alters depending on the player's surroundings and position. It is a game that will make you laugh, a little horny[2booty], cry, think, and feel. It is a game that will stay with you long after you finish it. It is a game that will change you(if you're open for the change)

145104469.review:
This is actually an odd game for me to review. I originally played this a few years ago for about 6 hours or so and got bored. Then recently I agreed on doing a game swap with a friend (I play a game they want me to play and they play a game I want them to play). While I wasn't particularly looking forward to playing this again, I'm glad I did. The game is basically one big artistic vision. There are some things I don't like but overall the game is good if you're into that kind of thing.

First thing to note is that this game has several different routes/endings. The first 2 routes play in the same time period and essentially you have to play through those bits twice but with some differences in perspective. However, the whole main story is played in a linear fashion so you can't miss out on any main route or ending. Anyway, I'll start with the things I liked:


[u]Positives[/u]

-Graphics are decent for a 2017 game, nothing amazing but it looks good.

-Sound effects are great.

-Variety of "plugin chips" to customise your gameplay, though I kinda just kept one set on for combat: counter+, anti-chain damage, max hp and auto-heal and never died ever again and then I had another set for when you play as 9S for hacking+ stats and auto-heal.

-The story from route C onwards was a lot more interesting than route A and B, though I will go into that more in the negatives part. The overall story was a great experience though and while route A isn't as good as the others, the prologue does start the game off strong. Some small details in route B are pretty nice and definitely appreciated.

-The music is an interesting one. On route A I felt like the music varied from "it's OK" to good, but then from route B onwards they start playing several variations of the songs and damn they are really good. You can really feel the emotion in the music and it's amazing.

-Chapter Select from finishing route C/D allows you to go back and finish stuff you might have missed.

-Customisable settings for the standard gameplay camera. Really cool.


[u]Neutral[/u]

-I didn't really vibe much with the combat which was one of the reasons why I stopped playing in my initial attempt at playing years ago. The movement feels kinda "floaty" and I didn't really like experimenting with different weapons much because the beginner sword is fast and does decent enough damage anyway. Could just be a me thing.


[u]Negatives[/u]

-The Route A part of the game is mostly "meh". Although it gains more value after finishing the game, on your first playthrough it can feel rather... generic gameplay-wise. The map is absolutely terrible to navigate and look at before you unlock more of it from the teleport vending machines. Fortunately map and side quest progression is saved throughout route progression. The main story in route A is purposefully simple and because of that it's kind of confusing at that point while you're playing as people do rate the game's story as good. Another thing to note is that they play the credits after you finish this route... so some people might actually think the game ends there when it actually doesn't.

-Route B is mostly the same Route A but with a perspective change, additional cutscenes and the ability to actually be able to finish some side quests you literally cannot finish in Route A. I already grasped what the story was going to be about 3 hours into route A, I didn't need to spend another 9~ hours in Route B to have it shoved in my face more. I wish they kinda cut this route down a bit and spent more time on route C/D+.

-Side quests. Oh boy. Some of the side quests are interesting but most are basically just showing you the same repeated theme of the game even more and IMO felt like a waste of time (I do get that it's supposed to add to the setup though). I just stopped doing side quests after finishing Route B and started enjoying the game more.

-Dynamic Camera -- I get that the camera being dynamic and changes angles is an artistic idea and it's kinda cool from an art perspective... But in some cases for the gameplay it sucks so much to play with and is frustrating.

-Most of the world map is frustrating. The Abandoned Factory is extremely annoying to traverse for side quests but at least it looks cool. The main city area (outside of the hub) is badly designed where there are loads of edges that you have to perfectly time your double jump for to climb up. Also in the same city there are parts that feel pointlessly blocked off so it forces you to have to walk around the side. In the desert you are able to slide around, but it's annoying more often than not as it cancels your sprint momentum.

145071729.review:
If our journey inevitably leads to the end, what truly is the purpose of life?
If life doesn't have a clear purpose, why do so many people work hard every day?

Imagine a scenario where machines emerge with potentially hostile intentions. Initially, they just function based on their programming, without genuine thought. But if they evolved to think autonomously, are they equal to us? If they are equal to us, why must we fight? If we don't fight, are we the ones who will suffer?

Such contemplation can birth unease and apprehension. And from these feelings, fear emerges. But it is the fear of those that are different than us that may ultimately be our undoing, guiding us down a journey filled with cruelty and anguish.

Who truly has the authority to determine life and death? Even when we're gone, the world keeps going. If that's the case, is there a point to living? Is there a point to feeling fear? Is there a deeper purpose to human existence?

Perhaps our bonds and connections with others provide a semblance of purpose. Without these ties, what gives life or even fear its significance? Someone with many bonds has an abundance of reasons to cherish life, while someone without such ties might struggle to find an anchor to hold onto in this existence.

I truly love this game.

144948126.review:
"NieR: Automata", desarrollado por PlatinumGames y publicado por Square Enix, es un título que ha dejado una profunda huella en la industria de los videojuegos. A través de una narrativa magistral y una exploración profunda de la filosofía, este juego se alza como una obra maestra que trasciende los límites convencionales de la experiencia de juego.

En el corazón de "Nier: Automata" yace una trama que se desenvuelve en un mundo posapocalíptico donde los humanos han sido expulsados de la Tierra por invasores mecánicos. La humanidad, al borde de la extinción, ha confiado su supervivencia en androides de combate, creando una inquietante paradoja: máquinas que luchan en nombre de los humanos contra máquinas invasoras. La historia se desenvuelve de manera magistral, explorando temas profundos como la identidad, la existencia, la conciencia y la moralidad.

La filosofía se infiltra en cada rincón del juego. Desde el existencialismo hasta la ética, "Nier: Automata" desafía constantemente al jugador a reflexionar sobre el propósito de la humanidad, la guerra, la tecnología y la inteligencia artificial. Los personajes, en particular los androides protagonistas, 2B, 9S y A2, experimentan un viaje emocional y espiritual que refleja las luchas y cuestionamientos inherentes a la condición humana.

La trama no solo se presenta a través de una narrativa convencional, sino que utiliza múltiples finales, cada uno de los cuales aporta una perspectiva única y significativa sobre la historia en su conjunto. Esta estructura narrativa intrincada invita a los jugadores a regresar una y otra vez para descubrir nuevos matices y detalles en la historia.

Además de su narrativa y filosofía profundas, "Nier: Automata" ofrece una jugabilidad emocionante y variada. Las secuencias de combate son frenéticas y satisfactorias, mientras que la exploración del mundo abierto y la interacción con personajes secundarios enriquecen la experiencia general. La banda sonora, compuesta por Keiichi Okabe, es simplemente asombrosa y complementa perfectamente la atmósfera del juego.

En resumen, "Nier: Automata" es una obra maestra que no solo desafía las convenciones de los videojuegos, sino que también invita a los jugadores a cuestionar su propia existencia y las decisiones éticas que enfrentan en el mundo real. Esta combinación de una narrativa apasionante y una filosofía profunda lo convierte en una experiencia inolvidable que trasciende los límites del medio y perdura mucho después de haber completado el juego.

Recomiendo comprarlo? Definitivamente.

Nier Automata es la obra culmen de Yoko Taro iniciada en Drakengard. Hace tantas cosas bien que es difícil hablar del juego en un resumen corto. Un hack and slash frenético que cambia la cámara en ciertos momentos en perspectiva cenital, 3D y scroll lateral. Además hay fases en los que jugaremos a un bullet hell de naves. Exploración, secundarias y un mundo semi-abierto en el que encontraremos secretos ocultos, armas, poderes y mejoras. De todo esto, lo único que le sobra es el crafting y sistema de mejoras, basada en farmeo indiscriminado de recursos.

[h3][b]Nota: A[/b][/h3]
Si queréis la mejor experiencia posible jugarlo con mando.

144881592.review:
[h1] Perpetual Existence and Finding Meaning [/h1]
NieR: Automata is the [b] SEQUAL [/b] to NieR Replicant, taking place some years after the events of that game. This is an action based game, with some sprinkle of RPG elements, where you play as 2B/9S, in a future Earth where Earth has been invaded and been taken over by machines and aliens.

The game itself has multiple endings. As the game itself is meant to be story rich and story heavy, in order to really experience the full story of the game, it is recommended for the player to go through each of the "Routes" to experience the full potential of the story. 

[h1] The Pros [/h1]
Let me get the first two things before hand. NieR: Automata has one of the best video game OSTs I've heard in the last 20 years of gaming experience and the story, [b] especially [/b] if you know the context from NieR Replicant, is practically a gaming masterpiece. The story talks about strong themes about finding meaning in life, and the world building Yoko Taro has in the Nierverse is intriguing to say the least. The game does an excellent job in keeping you invested on what is going on, and there isn't really a moment in the game's story where you feel anything is being forced or unnatural. By the last credits in Ending E, you would really feel a giant hole in your heart, even more so if you have played NieR Replicant. Note: playing NieR Replicant is not required to understand the story for Automata (as you will be playing from the perspectives from characters that are not present in Replicant), but playing Replicant does add a lot of context that makes emotional scenes hit even harder.

For the most part, the combat itself is pretty enjoyable. The animations are fluid, and though the combat itself isn't that complex, it's pretty satisfying to say the lease. It's very satisfying to master your dodges in-game, while you bash machines with basic combos.

Gameplay note: Side quests in this game, unlike Nier Replicant, are completely optional and you can skip all of them if you would like. However, side quests in this game are a pretty decent way to also further experience the world building story portion for Automata. Overall, most of the side quests consists of fetch quests and combat with the occasional puzzle based ones.
  
[h1] The Cons [/h1]
NieR Automata is almost a perfect game, but the PC port has some issues to take note of. The primary issue are the occasional graphical hiccups and texture pop-ins that does sometimes distract the players. Textures itself on the PC, vary from decent to something that looks like it's from the PS1 era. I've only experienced 1 lock-up during my 40 hours of gameplay (had to do a hard game restart, but only lost about 5-10 minutes of playtime at the time). Aside from that, if you could get used to the graphical hiccups, the base graphics itself for a 2016/17 game looks not bad.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Personal ratings:
Gameplay: 9/10
-Simple but satisfying combat
Graphics: 8/10
-Graphics look aesthetically pleasing at times. Occasional graphical issues on the PC port.
Music: 10/10
-One of the most memorable OSTs in any video games out there
Story: 10/10
-Amazing story. Masterpiece if you have played Replicant.
UI: 8/10
-UI and GUI is serviceable. Mini-map can be cluttered if you take on too many sidequests at once.
Overall Experience: 10/10
-Post-anime depression is real

Also note: the English dubbing in this game is very good. It is recommended to play this game in English first (if you do not know Japanese), as many dialogue can be missed during the middle of combat.

[h1] Ending Notes [/h1]
Came for 2B, stayed for existential depression, 15/10. Also you can pet the pods.

144541511.review:
TLDR: A masterclass in game design, direction, music score, gameplay mechanics, and writing. It keeps changing expectations as multiple hooks increase your momentum as you approach the ending. 

Not many games have the credentials to call themselves industry-changing, and it's not a necessity to do so. However, every now and then, one stands out with fresh takes on the medium, but only in some fields. Maybe it's the gameplay, art direction, or some cinematographic script that turns a game into a memorable experience. And yet, Yoko Taro brings us an example that shows us how boundless gaming can be as a medium for storytelling. From the get-go, one could say Nier: Automata is another Japanese action game with exaggerated character designs and a convoluted story, but as the player makes progress, it reveals itself as something far more engaging.

Gameplay is cinematic and makes use of a little robot companion with auto-lock to make it as flashy as possible, because just using your melee weapons alone won't give you the feeling of slashing through mobs of robots. Minigames that in other titles may feel bothersome or gimmicky are crafted so that the player never loses synergy in combat. Bullet hells are designed into enemy attacks, and sudden camera changes transform this game into many different genres in a matter of seconds. Role-playing elements with some inclusion of text adventure dynamics force the player to carefully consider the effects of some characters’ fates. There was no chance Nier: Automata could combine all these traits, and more, into its core without turning into a product held together with duct tape, and yet its formula finds a perfect harmony among all these elements to evoke all its themes.

If you’re into philosophy, this will be right up your alley. The compact game world and quests convey a dark future where existence is constantly being debated by artificial lifeforms. Without spoiling anything, its main cast go through many different perspectives regarding the human condition of being by exploring multiple thinkers and their works. The player might not be aware of all this existential baggage, but the messages are embedded for easy appreciation and, eventually, further reflection. It also helps that the game’s “routes” examine different angles on how to search for a purpose in life. Combined with a majestic soundtrack composed with perfect understanding of tone during gameplay, memories will be engraved into the player’s mind for a long time.

Of course, there are some flaws, as there are in every game. The start of the game is quite slow, maybe even sluggish. The map doesn’t help that much in tracking side quests. The auto-lock is your best friend, but sometimes it will not focus on the bigger threats you want to tackle first. And yet, I can guarantee you will overlook the rough edges around this gem. Even when the pace starts to get dull, or the gameplay stale, Nier: Automata will throw something new to keep you engaged and, eventually, give you a reason to see it through. The reason behind this is that, even if the game depicts a sad and meaningless world, certain [E]nding will convince you that life, indeed, is worth fighting for and full of hope. 

I hope this title inspires further developers into being more disruptive, creative, and inspiring. This game had no right for being so good while being so experimental, as there are some titles’ artistic visions that overwhelm their playability. And yet, Nier: Automata brought us one of the best experiences in gaming history. I hope everyone gets to enjoy it.

144430875.review:
Don't get me wrong, this game itself is wonderful. I love the game play and the story. It and works well on my computer and the Steam Deck.

My major complaint, which is why I am not recommending this game, is how cloud saves works: I had an issue once with my cloud save being wiped and had to restart my game. Goog thing I wasn't too far in my game. The other issue which is more irritating is that cloud saves carry screen settings between systems. This causes the graphics and screen size settings to change every time I switch between playing on my PC and my Steam Deck which have very different graphical settings. It is so annoying that this is something that was a choice by SquareEnix and/or PlatinumGames developers and even though in reality it is so small, it is annoying that they haven't fixed this already. I tried emailing their support to see if I could forward the issue and got this response:

"Thank you for contacting the Square Enix Support Center.

We understand you have concerns the display settings for NieR: Automata when changing platforms to play, and we'd love to help.

Updates in regards to the display settings being saved depending on the recent platform played is information that has not yet been announced and we are not able to comment at this time.

We do appreciate you bringing this to our attention, and rest assured that it will be forwarded to the appropriate party.

For now, you can stay up to date on our website (http://na.square-enix.com) for information on our products (both current and upcoming). We apologize we cannot assist further at this time.

Should you have any other questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to us and we'll gladly assist further.

Take care and stay safe!"

Hopefully this does get forwarded to the right someone, but this has been an issue for so long that I doubt it will ever be dealt with, especially for such an old game. If you are planning to play this game on only one PC and have the specs or only have the Steam Deck, it's a great game. If you want the flexibility of how you can play, I honestly can't recommend this game. Maybe if this changes I can give it the recommendation I would love to give this game.

144284958.review:
An incredible emotional and philosophical journey, NieR:Automata is a game and a story that will take your breath away and touch your heart again and again. And again. Maybe even another time. From beautiful scenery and epic battles to existentialist questions of the meaning behind concepts of life and death, love and hate, sacrifice and desire, and simply being human. An excellent merger of various video-game genres with seamless transitions, attention to detail, and near-limitless combat customization/movement techniques, all in a unique open-world map with an extraordinary soundtrack that words simply cannot describe. Truly an unforgettable and rewarding experience across all of its many endings.

Glory to Mankind.

144181193.review:
I really cannot recommend this, and I think this might be one of most overrated games I've ever played. I have finished route A and started B, dropped. This game should have been called NieR:Repetitive™

For the most part, characters are extremely bland. I think majority of people actually praising this game are doing because they are horny for 2B and p much every other female android because it was critical to the story to make every single female character sexualized. 

Combat and camera are biggest offenders of this game tho. Weapons are painfully boring. Combat stays the same from start to finish. Enemies are sponges, literally. U won't feel impact of hitting them, and they sometimes take forever to kill. Combat is incredibely easy because you can just abuse perfect dodge constantly, and it's insanely easy to pull it off. Game loves to change between 3d and 2d ( 2.5d? ) and it SUCKS. Platforming is terrible. Your support character is stupid, and will constantly get in a way of you. O yeah, did I forget to tell you that your character will constantly trip on any rock/wire/bush? XD

OST is good for the first time you hear it, but entering/existing zones automatically switches to their OST with no fade, it's insant. AND IT ALWAYS STARTS FROM THE BEGINNING. Boss OST slap tho.

Game looks incredibely cheap, I get that they wanted apocalypse amotsphere but amount of reused and copy pasted assets is ridiculus for game of this "quality". A lot of invinsible walls. You see huge opening in building? Well no, you can't enter it. 

Saving system is atrocious but I didn't mind it that much because game was so incredibly easy, it was really hard to actually die after initial prologue. 

Animations of character look amazing, and I never got bored of them. 

Story.. where do I start. I won't spoil, but you need to finish 2 routes in order to get to "good part". Keep in mind that route A has huge amount of bad sections, and B literally expands on them and makes them worse. Side quests for the most part are garbage ( there were few good ones, but sadly very little ). You can't fast travel until like first half of route A. And guess what, in route B you can't fast travel either until certain point in the story. Keep in mind that entire game is based on: start quest on X spot, run to Y, return to X. That's it. That's literally it. It's just running, running, bland combat, and running back. 

2/10 because of pretty animations and serviceable OST.

144133072.review:
A truly excellent game, with incredible depth.

The great:
The music in this game is just absolutely fantastic. Great variety, awesome ambience, beautiful and evocatively charged emotive works throught - makes you want to just pause and admire.

Voice acting is absolutely stellar too. Every character, even machines you're meant to think are emotionless and soulless, deliver their lines with meaning and gravitas.

Combat variety is wonderful and enemy types are very diverse, each giving you different types of difficulties, optimal approaches and flexibility in how you may choose to approach them. Sure, you may choose to just hack-n-slash them all to bits - but there's no "if you don't follow the dodge-dodge-x-dodge-jump-y-dodge-x-(...)"or whatever "formula" you lose without. Play to your strenghts and have your fun. This isn't a [with palpable derison] "souls-like" game...

The good:

Combat is reactive, varied, fast paced and wonderfully creative with multiple modes (odes to 2d side-scrollers, to 2d asteroids-like's, and more general 3d hack and slash and others) with an often wide range of tactics and strategy available to employ.
Controls can sometimes be a bit finnicky and unreactive (utilizing certain moves or attacks may often leave your character static longer than the animation would make it seem necessary, and your commands - dodge, attack, move - in that state would be ignored -- equally some "hold to complete" moves can be interrupted and without any indication you will be holding the button to no effect and need to repress - sometimes more than once - to continue) but for the most part, controls are very snappy and responsive.

The story is... Well, the story itself may be a bit of a tossup - a lot of it is built up on games you may have never played (the original NIeR released in 2010 I think, and maybe other media) -- but the delivery is engaging and fantastic. Lore is drip-fed in a way that causes enjoyable "I want to know more" effects, but lets you pace your way in.

Characters, for the most part, are very deep and get fleshed out progressively over playthroughs, letting you form bonds and actually care for and about them.

The not-so-great:
[minor SPOILERS]
I mentioned "playthorughs" so, yeah: This isn't a game you beat just once and move on. Or even just twice.
In fact, the first two playthroughs - the second of which offers expanded lore and cutscenes and different perspectives and dialogue on what you knew of from playthrough 1 ("A") - are merely the prologue for the latter part of the game - which greatly expands the lore, the setting, and the emotional aspects of the game itself. There are technically 27 endings to the game, though only 5 really matter (and the 4th and 5th don't require a full replay).

I got 6 endings (the most important 5, and a "joke" ending by accident) in around 36 hours so it's not that bad and while you may be asked to replay some dumb intro-fetch-side-quests, mostly the game remembers what quests you finished in the last playthrough and will not repeat them or let you start over where you were.

The bad:
Combat can be a bit unforgiving early before you have access and use of "plug-in chips" which give you boosts to damage and defense, auto-use of recovery items when you're critcally wounded, and other boosts which will dramatically change your gameplay options.
The game doesn't do a very good job of explaining how to use them, how they work, or how you can upgrade them by combination and/or build your own multiple chip decks to switch by need and opportunity.
But once you get the hang of it and build a deck or two that suits you, it is night-to-day.

In conclusion:
This game was a sleeper hit when it was released, blowing everyone away by its depth and approach to storytelling.
And with good reason.

I loved almost every second of it and hold it in very high regard. It may not be for everyone, but I think almost everyone will get some degree of wonder and a cherishable and great experience with it if they last at least as long as ending B.

I'm not sure I've ever wanted a game to end less. Just beat the A campaign, and diving into NG+. Thankfully, this game still appears to have plenty of fresh content.
I don't want to spoil anything, and I'm sure there's heaps I don't know yet. The campaign is really well paced, balancing reflective moments with crazy action. Although there were a few times where I dived into side content, every time I focused on the main missions I didn't want to put the game down. When the credits rolled it felt like the story was over, but I have so many questions.
The combat is amazing, and 2B's animations are some of the most fluid I've ever seen. Some games have difficulty balancing flashy animations with responsive controls, but this may be the best implementation I've played.
All in all, can't wait to dive in further and see what the rest of the game offers.

It is also incredibly flawed, and I could spend hours dissecting what I disliked about certain story beats, or certain characters.
It's a game full to the brim with pseudo-intellectual drivel that will make you want to yell at the screem.

143855235.review:
As of writing this review, I've played NieR: Automata about 6-7 times from beginning to end. My love for this game is so immense that I am able to get lost in it time and time again. My entire life I have always felt like an outsider. My interests are not what people would consider the norm. In that sense, this game is perfect for me, and has been perfect for me since I first played it in 2019. I'm not going to go into the specifics of the game in-depth, as this review is just going to be my love letter to this game.

NieR: Automata is what I consider one of the two most important stories I've experienced with the other being Umineko. The main messages that both stories share is love, and embracing the future. That sounds simplistic, but the ways in which the messages are portrayed have struck a cord with me that I don't think I'll ever forget. Reflecting on this game as I was playing it for this playthrough I've realized just how much of an impact this game has had on my worldview. Feeling alone all the time as a kid, I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted to do with my life, and all I ever really did was escape from the world. However, this game showed me humanity. The good and the bad, the beautiful and the ugly. This game is just so... human. The true ending of this game was eye-opening and showed me that others do care. It's humanist message has taught me a lot, and my future is more full of hope and love because of it. The world is full of fighting, and all manner of horrible things, but I believe in humanity. Thank you Yoko Taro, and everyone else who worked on this game.

You need to be patient with this game. Make sure you keep playing after you "finish" the game. The game words it awkwardly, but the "routes" work more like chapters, than replays with alternate endings. 

I've been gaming for almost 30 years and often feel jaded about videogames, in the sense that there's nothing left for me to see. This game constantly, and relentlessly subverted my every expectation. I'm very grateful for having given this game a chance, and I know that it is one of those few that will stay with me forever.

Don't be misled by the coomer memes, by the end you won't even be able to see the thighs through your own tears.

143446832.review:
This game is 100% worth picking up. The story is very engaging and the characters are ones you will want to spent time with. Also, gameplay is varied so you won’t get bored. There are lots of third-person action games, but also top-down, twin-stick shooter, side-scrolling platform, and the game moves smoothly between all of them. 

However, there are some issues. You slide a lot when you move, especially on sand, making picking up items from the ground irritating. There are also multiple parts where you have to walk extended distances while your character is injured, so you have to move very slowly. The first time I tried this part, I got punched behind some debris and got stuck for a while. Then I got punched down a hole I couldn’t escape from. Even the time I got through it without out issue was so very dull. Who thought this was compelling gameplay?

That said, it is still absolutely worth picking up, even at full price.

143445282.review:
This game is HIGHLY overrated. I can't believe some people consider it to be a masterpiece. It's mediocre at best.

1) Not a single character in this game has any personality. They are ALL so dull and ininteresting and their motivations make very little to no sense. I could not care less what happen to any character in this game.

2) The story tries to be subtle and intellectual but it's actually boring and pretentious. Calling this a "good story" is like calling a banana duct-taped to a wall "art". And to the people who say "You actually have to complete the game 3 times to have ending C to understand it and to make it good" just GTFO. It's like saying "You have to read all the Harry Potter books to make the first one good", it's just bullshit. First playthrough should be good on itself.


3) The open world is not ugly but it's not pretty either. It feels really outdated, even considering the game is from 2017. Everything is low-poly with mediocre textures. The only location that look "good" is the circus/fair. The world doesn't make you want to explore it. 

4) The combat system feels nice at first, but once you realise that you can be nearly invincible if you spam the dodge button, the combats lose ALL interest. Combine it with the fact that you can buy 99 small heals + 99 medium heals + 99 big heals for a fairly cheap price and you won't EVEN need to dodge attack. And finally, the combos and fighting possibilities lack a lot of depth and you fight every enemies in the same way.

5) There are some questionnable game design decisions that make the game tedious. For example, the fact that retrieving your body triggers 3 pop-up windows. Or the fact that you have to reactivate some teleporter mid-game. Or the fact that 2B stumbles on pebbles and rubbles. And many other small things that make the game annoying.

6) The "side quests" are nothing more than UPS quests: Talk to a NPC, go pick up 3 metal bolt in a field or talk to another NPC in the middle of nowhere then come back for reward. Some quests are a little more "interesting" like "kill this group of enemies in less than 30s" or "reach this destination on foot before the NPC" but that's about it....

The good things about this game are : 
-2b, you can clearly see that the devs spend more time on her than on any other characters or assets in the game. She has good design and she's well detailed.
-The animation (combat, runing, etc) are GREAT. That's the reason why combat and movements are enjoyable at time, even though combat is button smashing.
-All the mech phases/shoot'em up are good
-The music and sound design is good, except for some dialogues that are not dumbed for some reasons.

The game is not trash, but it's really dull, lame and even annoying sometimes (regularly).
I 100% believe that without the "waifu"/ "sexelegant" design of 2B, this game would have NEVER had that much attention and fanbase. People who worship this game have probably little to no cultural background to call that a masterpiece.

143442201.review: I guess it IS playable, but during playthrough it annoyed me in so many ways, i would not possibly recommend it. Starting with good ol' ps1 graphics, it prolongs with an odd story of "battle" androids, for whatnot reasons looking like a sex doll and a pedophile dream. Their behavior is random, motivations are uninspiring, there is no sympathy for them, on top of that, exloring the world is unrewarding, cuz most of items are just materials or ability "chips", which gives you no visualisations and makes you want to auto-equip them. Some parts of the game are pure cancer, especially when you need to go from point A to point B while being infected with the virus. Interesting concept of replaying the game from the POV of another character is ruined by a poor level design, basically making you replay same boring maps all over and over again, that being said without noting how many times you have to replay boring prologues if you want to achieve all the "endings" (most of which would be just a couple sentences of text). As a cherry on top, at the endgame you get hours of mindless grind if you want to do all the achievements (you can buy them INGAME though, which is a fckng joke as well). 143426362.review:
[b]Comment:[/b]
I was hesitant to play this game and expected to not enjoy it because of 2B butt meme and all that, but it's easily one of my all time favourite games. An amazing and beautiful game through and through.

[b]Good:[/b]
[list]
    [*] The soundtrack is amazing.
    [*] Captivating and emotional story.
    [*] I enjoy the world a lot.
    [*] Likeable cast of characters.
    [*] Character movement feels nice and fluid.
    [*] Interesting mix of different camera angles and gameplay elements for different areas of the game.
    [*] Plugin Chips (character enhancements) can be customized to suit your playstyle.
    [*] Side quests add to the experience rather than just being chores.
    [*] No difficulty based achievements.
    [*] Exploration is encouraged and rewarded.
    [*] Additional customization options within easier difficulty settings makes the game more accessible for people with disabilities.
    [*] Limited unofficial moddability, but it exists.
[/list] 

[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list]
    [*] Knowledge of previous installments adds to the experience, but is not required to enjoy the story.
    [*] Combat can be a bit button mashy.
    [*] The map and menu takes some getting used to.
    [*] 60 FPS lock. Unlockable, but speeds up certain elements so I don't recommend it.
    [*] Graphics look outdated for its time, but it doesn't make the game any less enjoyable.
    [*] Fan service in female character designs. Something to keep in mind if it's something you feel strongly about.
[/list] 

[b]Bad:[/b]
[list]
    [*] Without Movement Speed plugin chips, dashing is faster than running, incentivizing you to spam dash to move around.
    [*] I can't stop obsessing over it.
    [*] I hear the soundtrack playing in my head all day every day.
    [*] I even bought a body pillow.
[/list]

This feels like a budget AAA game, which isn't a bad thing. They don't quite have the super high production values of other AAA games but at the same time this allowed for some freedom and crazy and new ideas. I really enjoyed alot of stuff this game threw at me to change things up. Gameplay wise not sure how I feel about this. On one hand I really liked how this game starts out. It was a breath of fresh air. On the other hand some other gameplay elements felt very repetitive after a while but it was also cool to see them.

This is a story driven game, though. Can AIs have something resembling a spirit or soul? Or will they always just imitate having one and never exercise their true free will. Do most people even do that these days? It's hard to say. I don't want to spoil too much because this game is best left to play blind. 

The only other game that tackles these kind of questions (and better) that I know of is The Talos Principle. That's more of a puzzle game but it also doesn't have that weird Japanese "feel" if you know what I mean.

143370421.review: This game is heart-wrenching, gorgeously cruel, and agonizingly lovable masterpiece. I adore every aspect of this game, yet I have such a hard time going back to it, like many of the Nier/Drakengard games. The music and environments are a cinematic marvel, the characters feel so real and authentic even thought they are just characters in a video game (even more so amazing because they are androids.) I have never played a game that made me feel quite like Nier Automata did at the end. The only other game coming close being Drakengard 3. If you are looking to try a game in the series, I urge everyone to experience this one. Feelings aside, this game has great voice acting, beautiful environments, music that will make you swoon, combat that is so satisfying and rewarding to level up, and such a lovable cast of characters who feel very real in their struggles. I recommend this game to everyone I meet, but I also urge caution at the harrowing, heart-sobbing, tragically enchanting marvel that is Nier Automata.

143140793.review:
[i]From "Hehe, anime booty" to "It's painful to exist" in a span of first ten hours.[/i]

Telltale's The Walking Dead made me cry, sure, but Automata is the only game that made me tear up during "final" final credits instead. What an amazing experience. Glad that I went unspoiled about it for years and played it with zero knowledge now that I have a computer that is capable of running it.

Game's far from being new and considering that you are probably interested in it, I'll share only things that I [i]personally[/i] didn't really like about Nier: Automata:

• Route B (9S's route) is straight up painful to replay. You are effectively forced to replay the game AGAIN after beating it for the first time with zero to none alterations to story compared to first Route A. Pretty much exact thing that we've seen in original Resident Evil. Imo second character's point of view should have been completely optional. Second Act of the story is locked until you beat Route B. Honestly a questionable decision because apart from couple of scenes and cutscenes, 95% of the Route B is a direct copy of Route A.
• Yoko "Yes, I loved playing NES when I was young, how can you tell?" Taro. Overused twin stick shooter minigames in form of flight and hacking, especially during Route B. By the end of Route B I got so sick of it, I built 9S around direct combat instead of hacking.
• Difficulty balance? What difficulty balance? Normal difficulty is too easy, hard difficulty is too unfair (unless you enjoy getting one-two shot by an enemy that is not the most common class I suppose). I guess you'll be able to finish on Easy using only one foot. Feels like that there's supposed to be a difficulty in between but it's missing.

And... that would be it, honestly. Oh, and minor spoilers but I feel like I definitely need to mention this - special thanks to dev team for letting us to finish and leave the game without burning ourselves out. When you finish Route C, you are given an ability to [spoiler]straight up purchase achievements you have locked with in-game currency. Story-related achievements are non-purchasable but you are able to pick up every misc. achievement you miss[/spoiler]. You are still free to stick around and unlock everything yourself, of course. However this is a great help if you feel that you are "done" with the game and developer doesn't force you to see everything (especially considering how grindy most japanese games are), they appreciate you for seeing Nier: Automata through the end and I absolutely love it.

Do give it a shot if you are into "watashi no kokoro watashi no tamashi" games. You won't regret it, trust me.

Le pedí ayuda a mi hijo y organizó un juego para que yo me uniera. Me encantó porque era el mejor momento que había pasado con mi hijo desde que mi esposa había muerto. Desde entonces, este juego ha acercado a mi hijo y a mí nuevamente y ahora también pasamos tiempo juntos fuera de la casa. Este juego me recordó que hay diversión en todo, y nos ha traído tanto a mí como a mi hijo muchos recuerdos felices.

142966775.review:
[h1]NieR Automata is the first game to truly stand up and greet ludonarrative dissonance as a friend.[/h1]

There’s a choice you can make during the playable credits sequence of NieR Automata’s fifth and narratively conclusive ending: whether or not to make the ultimate in gaming sacrifices by helping a stranger, who you will never know or meet, with the game’s final challenge. It was a sacrifice I agreed to. I could say that I believed wholeheartedly that I wanted to help another player, especially since said final challenge is deliberately near-impossible, and it was only because of someone else’s sacrifice that I made it through. But in truth, I have no real answer as to why I willingly made the choice. The thought that keeps running through my head is a line from Matrix Revolutions: that the answer to why I persisted is simply because I chose to.

That ability to make carefully considered decisions that have no true purpose or meaning—the very core of free will—is a defining human trait, and the fact that this is something that cannot be taught or given to other living beings is a problem NieR Automata is almost pathologically fascinated with. It’s a fact it dances with, argues with, screams at, cries about, and mourns from its first seconds until the moment its final credit rolls. No, director Yoko Taro doesn’t have answers to the questions that the game poses, but he engages with what it means to be human in ways no game operating in AAA space has before, and certainly not one where you spend countless hours stylishly slicing up robots while dressed like the maître d’ at a FetLife dinner party.

NieR Automata lets its anime-inspired freak flag fly in the early hours of the campaign, giving absolutely no indication of the depths it will reach. Taro knows that 2010’s NieR was a thoughtful but mechanically uninspired game, which is why he brought in action-game savants Platinum Games to help assist with the sequel’s numerous gameplay styles. Within this game’s first hour, it’s at once a scrolling-screen Gradius-style shooter, a full-3D hack-and-slash action adventure, a 2D platformer, a tactical RPG, and a large-scale mech-combat jamboree. Later, the ability to damage enemies through a Geometry Wars-style mini-game becomes a gameplay staple. Throughout NieR Automata, it’s as if Platinum Games is showing off, and if they earn that braggadocio it’s because the developer excels at every single genre field the game chooses to play in—a rare jack-of-all-trades that masters all.

Most of the game, however, is spent in 3D-action mode, exploring a city-sized open world that strangely alternates minute to minute between PlayStation 2-levels of graphical austerity and breathtaking, lush moments of natural beauty that weren’t possible on that system. And all of it is bolstered by one of the most eclectic and evocative musical scores ever bestowed on a video game.

The game takes place 8,000 years into the future, where humanity has been supplanted by a race of deadly robots as the dominant species. Man’s last hope of retaking the planet is in an army of hyper-powered, silver-haired androids acting under orders from our lunar-based government to cleanse Earth of the machines. We initially play as 2B, a leather-clad, cold-hearted, all-business soldier who ends up saddled with 9S, a hacker-model android with the personality of an awkward 14-year-old. Their mission is simple reconnaissance and errand-running at first, with a plethora of machine-crushing sidequests and plenty of the kind of varied, large-scale, multi-part boss fights that Platinum is famous for (and accessible here within a couple of playtime hours). The waters get muddy fast, though, once it turns out the robots may not all be the mindless killing machines humanity says they are.

It’s obvious upfront that something might be off, as the supposedly lethal robots are redolent less of Terminators or the Borg than they are of the kindly robots from Hayao Miyazaki’s Castle in the Sky, only dwarf-sized. Most of them wander aimlessly, and many of them don’t even attack when 2B or 9S wander too close. One particular robot, Pascal, waves the white flag the second he sees 2B, and invites her to a village where robots have discovered the futility of war, and have begun trying to figure out what to do with their sentience. Despite no physical resemblance or similarity to humans, across the world, the robots clumsily fumble toward humanity, savoring our joys, and dreading our mistakes in equal measure. One of the game’s more bizarre, yet oddly affecting moments has our heroes coming across a hidden enclave full of robots trying to approximate human love by rocking empty cradles back and forth while chanting the word “child,” miming sex acts on each other, and screaming out for someone—anyone—to hold them.

Despite working in a genre whose ethos more or less relies on the concept of killing anything that moves, at any given moment, the game confronts the player with the shared values and ongoing personal development of the Other, and gives us multiple options, including flat-out murder, for engagement with it. There are narrative and gameplay consequences and advantages that result from every decision. Even the necessary fights against the deadliest of characters have justifications that require a measure of understanding and empathy from the player. NieR Automata is the first game to truly stand up and greet ludonarrative dissonance as a friend, and actually start the conversation about our bloodlust versus our empathy, while not short-shrifting the argument for either side.

Taro employs every dirty game-design trick in the book to get his points across, up to and including some of the mind-trippy visual distortions in the game’s user interface, and it’s all in favor of story above all else, which never once takes the easy way out. Said story isn’t afraid of offering up a high body count, indulging in non sequiturs, or laying a guilt trip on a particularly cool gameplay segment, and in general is utterly fearless at bringing us face to face with what it means to have latent humanity in a game genre that so very often holds empathy in contempt. There’s power and glory to be had while playing NieR Automata, and perhaps the greatest testament to what’s been created here is how much of that glory involves mercy, not murder. And that, coming from the developer whose greatest moment prior to this one involved a gun-slinging witch punching the face of God into the sun, is miraculous.

142954856.review:
When I heard that this game was a story-rich ARPG with 26 endings, I knew I had to completionist it, and coming out of the other side of it I'm both impressed and disappointed. 
Off the bat, the story is perfect for this kind of game, simplistic in it's story telling with a lot of subtext to be explored, characters comparable to the likes of studio ghibli, and successfully avoiding ludo-narrative dissonance. For the most part, the core gameplay isn't anything special but is robust and interesting enough to hold up across 60 hours without getting stale. I say for the most part because of a handful of bullshit difficulty spikes (mostly during remote control sections) and a lot of RNG heavy grinding, although the latter is mostly a result of completionism.
My main disappointment came from the potential of this world and the message behind the game. after finding out that only 6 of the endings are meaningful and the rest are jokes kind of removed the impact of even having 26 endings but the linearity of the main endings still creates a significantly rich story. I only hope that the prequels will make up for this.
After all I've said and done, I'd still highly recommend this game and as long as you expect to only have 6 significant endings you won't be disappointed by them (and you'd know when you're done), and don't be afraid to lower the difficulty if the bullshit spikes are hurting your enjoyment of the game.

142881958.review:
NieR:Automata is a game I have 100%'d and would do so again in a heartbeat. Between the gripping (and sometimes cynical) story, engaging gameplay, extremely iconic characters, and masterfully composed (and dynamic) music, there is something for almost anyone here. Give it a try, I truly believe it's one of the greatest video games and expressions of any story that has come to visual media. If nothing else, the opening mission is a great way to get a taste for the intensity of the story, atmosphere, and two main characters (extremely reminiscent of the opening mission from FFVII which is also a fantastic introduction) and it shouldn't last longer than 2 hours, in case you don't like it.

There aren't many downsides I have with this game but one of the only ones is the port. It was a game made for the PS4 rather than PC, and it shows with its performance. Though I've had one of the better experiences (from what I've seen), the game still drops frames occasionally and may not be great for lower spec PCs.

I can't think of any other cons at the moment but if you're considering trying this game out, take it from a random internet person like myself: This game is amazing.

142872635.review:
After finally finishing routes A, B, and C over a period of around 42 hours, I've got a pretty good understanding of the game's story, I think. But it's written by Yoko Taro, so who knows.

I'll try to keep the spoilers minimal.

THE GOOD:
- The story has some pretty strong themes of existentialism here, following characters as they struggle to find meaning in a world filled with tragedy and pointless conflict.
- In the tradition of the first NIER game, the game plays with camera angles to seamlessly transition between genres. Get used to the game changing camera angles on the fly.
- The combat in this game is satisfying, and can get pretty hectic--there's a lot to manage so you'll flex those situational awareness muscles.
- The hacking minigame is lots of fun.
- The final (Route C/D) dungeon/boss was awesome and I wish more games tried to use mechanics for storytelling and dramatic effect. Honestly most of Route C was fantastic.
- Fleshing out some details about the first NIER and linking the two together was nice, considering how otherwise disjointed from its predecessor the game can seem.
- Keiichi Okabe's music is top-tier--probably the best video game soundtrack I've ever heard. The only other thing that comes close for me is the music from the first NIER.
- Character designs and just the art design in general is great.
- Voice cast is great in both Japanese and English. Unlike so many Japanese games I've played--even ones from the same publisher--the dub is of high quality.

THE MEH
- The story can feel pretentious; sometimes it beats you over the head with its themes when it doesn't really need to. This being said, sometimes the story wasn't all that clear either. It's a heavy story that doesn't always need the anime-style tropes that sometimes pop up.
- Having to play through the first campaign again to get to Route C isn't great--I found myself blitzing through content and skipping cutscenes I'd already seen. Luckily Route B only took me about 4 hours.
- For a game by a studio that prioritizes 60fps, having 30fps cutscenes was certainly a choice.
- Not 100% sure why they reintroduced Emil into this game just to be a shopkeeper. I'd have hoped for a little more there.

THE UGLY
- This game does not look amazing at high resolutions. Most textures (not all) were pretty muddy and the level of foliage was low, even by 2017 standards. I ended up using texture packs to clean things up a bit.
- The port is better than it was in 2017, but still has some issues. I alt-tabbed during a cutscene and when I came back the game was stuck in windowed mode, even when using mods to fix graphics issues.
- Speaking of that... PC games should not require modders to fix basic program functionality. I'm thankful they do, but they shouldn't have had to in the first place.

THE VERDICT

NIER:Automata is an incredibly fun game that does great things with the medium and tells a solid story with heavy themes. I personally think it may be a tad pretentious and a bit overhyped, but it's still one of my personal favorites.

142678763.review: The term "masterpiece" gets thrown around a lot in gaming, but in the case of NieR:Automata it is truly earned. This is one of those rare gaming adventures that I wish I could experience for the first time again. The visual design, graphics and gameplay are all superb and effortlessly transition into different genres all the while being underscored by an unforgettable and dynamic soundtrack. The game is constantly evolving in surprising ways much like the machine lifeforms you'll be combating throughout the story. All of this would be enough to make NieR:Automata a top-notch action RPG but what really makes this game important is the questions it asks you through the combination of all of these elements. NieR:Automata doesn't just ask what it means to be a video game, but what it means to be a conscious being in a godless universe. Yoko Taro and the PlatinumGames crew have used the medium of video games to tell a story that can only be told through the interactive medium. NieR:Automata is a showcase of the power of video games, not just as entertainment, but as art. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll have an existential crisis or two and maybe you'll learn something about yourself and those around you.

142594073.review:
Many potential players might dismiss Nier:Automata based on their initial exposure to it. The game's character design is visually appealing and popular in cosplay and fan-art communities, and this is the content that sparks interest on social media. As a result, these characters have gained immense popularity among people who haven't actually played the game, leading to a superficial perception of the game, or worse still, complete ignorance of the games existence.

Some individuals may approach the game with expectations of finding more visual, sexual stimuli, while others might be discouraged by the vacuous references they've encountered online, assuming the game lacks substance.

However, once players delve into it, they will find a narrative and characters that are certainly not lacking in substance. It would be a disservice to spoil anything specific about the story, so I will leave my description vague. But I will say that the game blends exposition and implicit world-building and has an emphasis on thought provoking philosophical themes.

The music is exceptional. There is a running joke within the Nier community that these games are like buying a soundtrack with a game thrown in as an added bonus.

From a technical standpoint, while the games graphics may look a bit dated, with plenty of low resolution textures and few detailed models, but the art style is inspired and consistent. Many of the environments are able to be beautiful despite having a minimalistic design.

The gameplay is particularly interesting in the way it blends different genres. At first glance, the games appears to be a 3rd person action, brawler, but it cleverly incorporates elements of RPGs, shmups, bullet-hell, platforming, and more. Side quests, collecting weapons and upgrades, and a fishing mini-game further enrich the gameplay and replayability.

One aspect often overlooked is the game's general feeling of movement and combat. The developers specifically intended to create highly satisfying and enjoyable character movement, and they succeeded in this goal. Many other action games could learn from the techniques employed in this game.

Despite its widespread popularity, Nier: Automata is such an excellent game that it could arguably be considered underrated. Personally, I find it difficult to overstate just how exceptional this game is, ranking it among my favorite pieces of media ever.

142592398.review: Buy it. One of the best games ever made.

142590174.review:
A Sci-Fi Symphony for the Senses: Experience the Brilliance of NieR:Automata

Step into the captivating world of NieR:Automata, where mind-bending sci-fi meets epic storytelling, and prepare to be taken on a whirlwind of emotions and adrenaline. As a seasoned gamer, I can confidently say that this masterpiece of a game is nothing short of groundbreaking in its execution.

One of the first things that struck me about NieR:Automata was its stunning visuals. From the desolate ruins of a post-apocalyptic Earth to the mesmerizingly beautiful cityscapes, every frame was meticulously crafted to immerse you fully in this dystopian universe. The attention to detail is awe-inspiring, and the juxtaposition between the vast open-world environments and intimate interiors is seamless.

But visuals alone do not make a game unforgettable; it's the depth of its narrative that truly sets NieR:Automata apart. Prepare to contemplate the very essence of what it means to be human, as the game delves into existential themes with an elegance rarely seen in this medium. The thought-provoking exploration of identity, consciousness, and the blurred lines between humans and machines will keep you pondering long after you put down the controller.

As for gameplay, NieR:Automata shines. Its combat system is fluid, responsive, and incredibly satisfying. Decimating waves of enemies with graceful acrobatics and a mesmerizing array of weapon combos feels utterly exhilarating, and the game's dynamic difficulty adjustment ensures that you are continuously challenged without being overwhelmed.

However, what truly elevates this game is its hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, composed by the masterful Keiichi Okabe. Every note and melody is carefully woven into the fabric of the game, seamlessly blending with the visuals and narrative to create an auditory experience that transcends the boundaries of gaming. From somber piano pieces to soaring orchestral arrangements, the music of NieR:Automata stays with you long after the game ends, reminding you of the emotional journey you embarked on.

In conclusion, NieR:Automata is a truly remarkable game that combines stunning visuals, thought-provoking storytelling, exhilarating combat, and an unforgettable soundtrack. It pushes the boundaries of what a video game can achieve and leaves a lasting impact on anyone fortunate enough to experience it. Strap in, embrace the unknown, and prepare for a symphony of emotions that will resonate within your Soul.

142531446.review:
A Masterpiece of Emotion and Adventure - Nier: Automata Shines Bright!

Rating: ★★★★★

As a lifelong gamer, I have experienced countless virtual worlds, but few have left a lasting impression as profound as Nier: Automata. This game is nothing short of a masterpiece, blending an emotionally charged narrative, breathtaking visuals, and exhilarating gameplay into an unforgettable journey.

From the very start, Nier: Automata grips you with its captivating story. The plot explores profound themes like identity, purpose, and the essence of humanity, all while unraveling a mesmerizing post-apocalyptic tale. The game's characters are richly developed, each carrying their own burdens, and their struggles resonate deeply with players. From the enigmatic 2B to the quirky 9S and even the rogue-like A2, the protagonists' journey is an emotional rollercoaster that tugs at your heartstrings and leaves you pondering long after you've turned off your console.

Visually, Nier: Automata is a breathtaking marvel. The world is gorgeously crafted, ranging from desolate ruins to lush forests, and each environment feels alive with meticulous detail. The contrasting landscapes complement the game's thematic depth, and the unique art style gives the game a distinctive and unforgettable look. Character designs are striking and complement their personalities perfectly, adding an extra layer of immersion to the overall experience.

However, the true brilliance of Nier: Automata lies in its gameplay. PlatinumGames' signature action-packed combat blends seamlessly with RPG elements, creating an addictive and fluid system that never ceases to amaze. The smooth transitions from intense aerial battles to ground-based combos make every encounter feel like a beautiful dance of blades. The variety of weapons, combined with a customizable pod that provides different abilities, ensures that combat remains engaging and satisfying throughout the game.

Furthermore, the game cleverly implements multiple gameplay styles, ranging from intense hack-and-slash sequences to bullet hell-inspired shoot-'em-up segments. These inventive changes keep the gameplay fresh and exciting, preventing any sense of monotony from setting in.

Beyond the main story, Nier: Automata features a plethora of side quests and optional content, each offering valuable insights into the game's world and characters. These diversions are thoughtfully crafted, contributing to the overall narrative and providing an opportunity to further connect with the beautifully crafted characters.

Moreover, the game's soundtrack is nothing short of spectacular. The hauntingly beautiful melodies, coupled with hauntingly poignant vocals, further amplify the emotional impact of key moments. Composer Keiichi Okabe's work is an auditory marvel, enhancing the immersive experience and making it an essential component of the overall package.

In conclusion, Nier: Automata is a gaming gem that leaves an indelible mark on all who venture into its world. It deftly combines an emotionally charged narrative, stunning visuals, and exhilarating gameplay to create an experience that transcends the confines of traditional video games. This is not just a game; it's an emotional odyssey that will stay with you long after the credits roll. If you are seeking a profound, thrilling, and emotionally rich gaming experience, Nier: Automata is an absolute must-play.
