142451348.review:
If you are familiar with Yoko Taro and his work, then you will know exactly what I mean when I say that [i]NieR: Automata[/i] is an [i]experience[/i]. And if you've played any of his other games to completion, you'll know pretty much what to expect from this one. But if you aren't familiar with Yoko Taro, there are a few things you should know about him before listening to the hype. Bear in mind that none of these things are intended to dissuade you from playing [i]Automata[/i]--to the contrary, I very much think that you should!--but setting some expectations ahead of time will prepare you to have the best possible experience with this game.

The first thing you should know about Yoko Taro is that he is out to troll you. He knows what the average gamer will expect from a video game, and he will absolutely take full advantage of that knowledge to mess with you at every turn. Some of the ways he messes with you will be fun, subverting your expectations in an enjoyable way. Others will be frustrating beyond belief, but constructed in such a way that you will either feel compelled to overcome them or give up and throw the game on your backlog to gather dust. Be forewarned, this is true many times over for completionists--the man has no compunctions whatsoever about wasting your time, and it's easy to imagine that some of the decisions that made it into this game, did so solely because he thought they would be funny at your expense. None of them will prevent you from completing the story, but many of them will crop up in incredibly annoying ways if and when you go for 100% completion.

The other thing you should know about Yoko Taro is that he is weird, and his games reflect that. He is a man that wears the head of one of his characters over his own head at all times in public. (His answer changes every time someone asks him why.) He includes attractive women in skimpy outfits in his games, not for any purportedly thematic reason as some creative types do, but simply because he openly likes ogling them. (This should answer the all-too-common question of why 2B is wearing a maid outfit in [i]Automata[/i].) All of his games include outlandish (and often horrifying) plot developments and colorful characters who are all broken in a variety of strange and tragic ways. If anything, [i]Automata[/i] is easily the most grounded of all of his games up to this point, but those who have played the [i]Drakengard[/i] series or the original [i]NieR[/i] will know that isn't saying much.

[b]So if [i]NieR: Automata[/i] is a weird game with trollish elements made by a weird guy with a fetish for maid outfits and spherical head-helmets, why should you play it?[/b]

Because it is very, [i]very[/i] good. It will surprise you in ways I can't explain due to spoilers. It will delight you with its [i]beautiful[/i] soundtrack and deliciously smooth free-flowing combat, courtesy of the character action masters at PlatinumGames. It will shock you with revelations that completely recontextualize earlier parts of the game, making the multiple playthroughs required to see all of the endings (and the all-important "true" ending) feel earned and worthwhile. It is one of those rare games where everything, even the trollish bits, were included for a specific reason to elicit a specific reaction, and that reaction lands damn near every time. It's a roller coaster ride of a game, in more ways than one, and it's an [i]experience[/i] you won't quite get in almost any other game.

I talk in some of my reviews about intentionality in game design, usually in the context of a mediocre developer just throwing some stuff into their game because they thought it sounded good or because it's what other games are doing. [i]NieR: Automata[/i] is the antithesis of this way of doing things, down to the smallest details, like the options menu [spoiler]being structured like a console for the android you're controlling[/spoiler]. I can't think of a single thing about this game that wasn't incorporated for a reason, even if that reason is as silly as Yoko Taro wanting to mess with players by [spoiler]making it nearly impossible to catch a certain specific fish in order to complete a pointless log[/spoiler], just because he knows that will bother some people.

TL;DR: Play this game. Ignore the hype, go into it with an open mind, and see it through to the true ending (which requires three playthroughs, but trust me, that's a good thing).

ADDENDUM (minor spoilers for a sidequest): A quick note to those who harp on about the "deep philosophical themes" in this game--[spoiler]remember the "Jean-Paul's Melancholy" side quest? The one with the haughty existentialist machine who is too good for his followers' gifts? Remember how that quest ended? That's Yoko Taro laughing at you. Just so you know. ;P[/spoiler]

142287383.review:
I will be very passionate and dedicated when I say that this is the best video game I have ever played.
Everything about it is perfect or nearly perfect.

1.Gameplay
Smooth and diverse with every weapon. Micro building feels like it actually affects gameplay, but if you don't care about that you can also just do whatever and still succeed. It's the perfect combo of the both. My only complaint is that heavy swords don't really do anything and that level kind of only exists. Apart from that every boss encounter is unique and feels like a passionately build level on its own. 

2.Story
This is by far the best story I have ever seen. Every little detail has a meaning from beginning to end, the world feels alive and very realistic in a sense that is hard to describe. The story also constantly evolves what it is about and the 5 main "routes" show that perfectly. One moment you'll be sitting here playing some random Japanese anime robot vs androids game and the next you'll be confronted with hardcore philosophical questions, that the game tries to answer. Nothing about the story feels manufactured and therefore it's immersive and very relatable. This is especially seen very near the end. I won't spoil the details, but be ready to have your mind blown multiple times and confronted with very intense dialogue.

3.Music
This cannot go unadressed. If you thought all of this sounded pretty good just wait till you hear the music. Every song is a banger and perfectly underlines the tone of the game. Never in your life have you heard such a perfectly fitting soundtrack. 

Conclusion:
NieR:Automata is a timeless masterpiece and another perfect entry in the Yoko Taro game selection. It's sad the NieR story is over now and we won't see this world again. As for now this game is an easy recommendation and a 10/10 and the only game I would call nearly flawless in it's core.

It's the sense you get when playing that you are taking part in a story that really, truly matters. The soundtrack is one of the best that I have ever heard in a game, I listen to it in my free time when I'm not even gaming and I almost never do that with any other games.

The way it plays is kind of a combination of a twin stick shooter (Pod mechanic) and a hack and slash/character action game but without an emphasis on combos. But there are also airborne sections which play like a mech style of game. It never got boring to me and I was really bummed when the credits rolled, not because the story was bad ...only because the story was over and I really wanted it to keep going. Luckily, I found out that the game has multiple endings and you have to play through it several times to get the true ending.

The voice acting and storytelling is top notch, it is better than many games with much higher budgets. There is a new Anime series that was recently released and it is equally well done. Yoko Taro (the writer/director of the game) is the greatest and I hope Square is working with him to make a sequel to this game, it would truly be a mistake not to. 

If you see this game available for $20, by all means, do grab it. Although it is totally worth $40, I own it on Steam and Nintendo Switch because that port was amazing.

142266638.review:
A Worldbuilding Masterpiece. It's simply incredible how well this world was constructed and expanded upon in NieR and NieR: Automata.

The game takes place several millennia after the first installment, which is why you don't immediately recognize the world. However, all the important locations, although completely devastated, hidden, or expanded, are still there. Through archive data and dialogues, you can also learn why the world has evolved in this way.

The story is also on its own level. By repeatedly shattering the worldview, it can be compared to Attack on Titan. But there are also numerous side quests that add even more depth to everything. Along the way, you are constantly confronted with moral questions that are not so easy to answer and leave you pensive.

The gameplay is perfectly executed, as expected from Platinum Games. 2B controls in a hack-and-slash manner, while 9S provides a good variation through machine hacking, which also supports the worldbuilding by allowing us to experience the emotions and thoughts of the machines.

The graphics, and especially the soundtrack, are beautiful as well. I haven't seen anywhere else where the OST consists of a mix of different languages, which is intended to represent a kind of future language.

I've completed the game in its entirety for the second time now, including all the endings and side quests, and it has definitely made it into my top 10 games. I'm really excited to replay NieR: Replicant now.

142261277.review:
[h1]NieR:Automata is a masterpiece[/h1]

[i]Spoiler free[/i]

[h2]Summary[/h2]
NieR: Automata uses every element of a video game (gameplay, storytelling, perspective and character building, music, the enviroment etc etc) woven together to create a story and convey emotions in a way that can only be done through the medium of a video game. 

When I saw the screenshots and trailers of the game I did not want to play it. But years later I'm glad I finally did. And like any piece of art it might not resonate with you, but if it does... 

...well here is one of the best games you will ever play.

[h2]The story[/h2]
Gameplay wise the game starts with a bang.
The story starts slow, but picks up and is a big part of why this game is a masterpiece.

(slight spoiler ahead about how you engage with the story not about it's contents) 
[spoiler]When you think you first finished the game, but have so many unanswered questions know that this is the whole point of the game. You go through the story again (and quicker, and different) through a different lens and start unpacking the story bit by bit. It caught me by surprise how much I liked this aspect as I'm not one to replay singleplayer games.[/spoiler]

You will not understand everything at first.
One tip I can give is to keep going forward and don't waste too much time on sidequests (at first) that you don't like or stuff you don't understand. Keep going forward 2B.

[h2]The soundtrack[/h2]
It's insanely good and I really mean 10 out of 10 good. It's not just that the songs are great and well composed. How the music fluently intertwines with where you are and what you're doing is something I have never seen before in a game. How does this work? Well: every track has multiple versions on top of that there are versions with and without vocals and if that wasn't enough most of them have an 8 bit retrofied version to fit a certain gameplay element.

[h2]The combat system[/h2]
The combat system is very simple at first glance but is actually deep and intricate if you are willing to go for it. So it's really up to you if you want to engage in the beauty that the combat system has to offer. Different characters offer different playstyles and depending on the weapons you wield you open up more deviations and different combos. The combat is also as smooth as it can be.

[h2]The RPG elements[/h2]
The RPG elements of building your character are light but set up in a smart way that really fits the theme of the game. I wont go into much detail and again you can choose to not really engage with the system but if you start doing so (for example later in the game) you'll have a lot of fun.

[h2]Does it feel dated?[/h2]
Stylistically it's beautiful and the game does not feel that dated. 
A lot of newer games can learn from the action and RPG elements you will find here.

[h2]Does it run on the Steam Deck?[/h2]
Yes, this game should be Steam Deck verified, because Proton was made with NieR:Automata in mind (no joke) and you'll feel that when you run the game. I played 90% of the game on the Steam Deck.

142137802.review:
It's aight.

I won't delve into the gameplay side of things, it's pretty universally accepted that the gameplay of NieR:Automata is mediocre. The story is seen as absolutely incredible though, which it isn't, it's also fairly mediocre.

I don't doubt that when the game came out the story was profound and revolutionary, now though, it's just your typical "AI/human realises AI can be conscious" story. You've seen stuff like this way more times already, and a lot of those times done far better. The characters are one dimensional and experience a very linear character arc. AI believes machines aren't conscious and they want to kill them all; AI faces proof that the machines are conscious, still doesn't believe they're conscious and wants to kill them; AI after a lot of proof realises that the machines are conscious but still kills them anyway; machines did something bad to the AI, now AI wants to kill all machines and believes they're not conscious; AI realises machines are conscious and no longer wants to kill them; THE END.

The characters also have additional character arcs involving them realising they like someone as a friend, in an equally linear way.

Side quests barely have any story to them, it's mainly that they'll throw a random concept out there like idk a machine having a sister, and then just leave you with that concept without any real conclusion aside from "they lived happily ever after".

For the first 20h, basically no story is told at all, nothing profound, nothing really that interesting, there's a couple mysteries thrown around too, but we know literally nothing about them. Then for the next 10h or so you'll find out what all that story before meant, and then for the last 5h or so you'll get the conclusion to that story with some honestly fairly decent plot twists.

I'd give this a mixed review if I could, but well steam doesn't have that. If you've never experienced any media portraying the same themes as this game, and or you don't really have any of your own opinions about this, then you'll probably thoroughly enjoy the story, otherwise I wouldn't really recommend it, aside from just taking it out of your backlog.

6.5/10

I had a hard time getting into this one but I'm really glad I persevered.  I spent a lot of time on route A (32 hours) and mostly enjoyed it when I played but found it forgettable and it rarely stuck with me when I wasn't playing.  The combat is mostly combos and dodging and frankly I'm just not very good at that.  I found the opening hour impossible until I changed started playing on easy.  I often didn't know what I was supposed to be doing and there often seemed to be very intentional barriers to actually enjoying it.  

All of that changed toward the end of route A and the story really picked up.  Route B isn't a repeat AT ALL-  combat was suddenly a twin-stick shooter and it was much quicker (maybe 7 hours).  Routes C/D took another 11 hours and the story got really intense.  Ah- that's what people are  talking about.  I get it now.  

Its a serious time investment but while the first half of this game did very little for me the 2nd half was absolutely brilliant.

This is the best game I have ever played. I don't think I could say it's my favorite, but I can say it is the best, and it's not close. Nier Automata is the most beautiful treatise on the human condition I have experienced, and it has basically no human characters at all. It's truly a masterpiece.

141970748.review:
The plot and character development alone is worth the price of admission. Gameplay has a decent blend of action RPG and classic elements(complete with the 8-bit sound effects), but it could be described as a bit generic in it's execution. This game isn't very pretty and some may even describe the art style at first glance as drab, empty and ugly aside from the main character models, but after a few hours of playing it kind of makes sense with the general mood of the game.  

All that said, the first bit of praise is the most important. If the plot and characters weren't as fascinating as they were, I wouldn't enjoy this game. I did find that it took a long time for me to get invested, and this was 
after I strongly considered getting a refund because I wasn't having fun with the gameplay. 

Oh, and this game has undoubtedly the best New Game+ I have ever experienced in a video game, and it's not what you think it is.

141897551.review:
So, this very quickly became one of my most beloved games. Fun gameplay (Hack n Slash with some bullet hell/shoot 'em up segments to keep things fresh), beautiful and very memorable soundtrack, and a really well written, emotional story that gets you thinking.

There are a couple of annoying things, such as the lack of checkpoints during the prologue. For this reason I highly recommend starting the game on Normal (or even Easy if you want) until you get to the first save point, then turn it up to your preferred difficulty if you feel so inclined. The mouse & keyboard controls are also not great, I would highly recommend playing with a controller if you want the best experience.

Anyway, if you're even a little bit curious, I would highly recommend giving this game a chance. It truly is something special.

141887751.review:
This game sucks, it's a sci-fi dmc knockoff that tries to be multiple things at once.
Forced cameras that are worse than resident evil, platforming worse than ratchet and clank, bullet hell worse than Contra, and hack and slash worse than DMC or the warriors games.
If I have to go through this game multiple times just to "get the actual ending" while playing mediocre gameplay at best then there is an issue. The level system shouldn't even be in here, give the enemies a health bar instead. The chip system is unique but hot garbage. 
nier: automata wants you to explore and fish and upgrade your gear and shit, but still feels like you're hitting enemies with a feather. i.e. I was level 20 with good chips equipped and it took me at least 10 sword swings and my pod gatling to kill a LEVEL 2 ENEMY.
Then it has the audacity to say hey, you beat the game, we actually have more endings. Play our lame game again. 

TL:DR the only good thing to come from this game is the soundtrack.

141788839.review:
Comenzando el viaje con 2B y 9S, nunca esperé experimentar una tormenta de emociones tan fuerte al jugar en un género que no es mi favorito.

La misión habitual de destruir máquinas Goliat y recopilar información sobre ellas resultó ser fatídica para nuestros héroes, entrelazando sus vidas de manera muy fluida.

Después de un prólogo lleno de tensión y horas de desafío en el modo difícil, el juego pareció dar un respiro al ofrecerme la oportunidad de salvar por primera vez.

Al explorar la Tierra recién descubierta, NieR finalmente me permitió disfrutar de lo que más me gusta: explorar lentamente paisajes inmensos y conmovedores. Desde la deslumbrante blancura del desierto hasta los magníficos fuegos artificiales en el parque de atracciones, y luego sumergirme en la vegetación que envolvía el castillo medieval. A medida que avanzaba, recopilaba información sobre los antiguos habitantes del planeta y estudiaba el comportamiento de androides y máquinas a través de misiones secundarias, intentando comprender qué tan cerca o lejos están de la humanidad. Otras veces, simplemente disfrutaba pescando junto a una cascada.

De vez en cuando, el juego parecía divertirse conmigo, en lugar de al revés. NieR alternaba entre ser un shooter, un juego de plataformas, un juego isométrico e incluso un desafío de balas infernal.

Una vez que te abres al mundo y a los personajes de NieR, no hay vuelta atrás. El juego, con su sofisticación y acentos hábilmente colocados, te conecta fácilmente con sus héroes, villanos e incluso personajes secundarios a quienes puedes ayudar en tus viajes. Sin embargo, te aplasta con un final inevitable que se revela en un drama lujoso y cruel, cada vez que completas una nueva vuelta (sí, porque debes jugar al menos tres veces para obtener el cuadro completo).

Además de los finales canónicos de la historia, hay muchos otros finales, en su mayoría negativos, que encuentras en situaciones inesperadas a medida que avanzas. Aunque solo he descubierto un par de ellos por mi cuenta, aún sigo terminando el resto.

Jugar con cada uno de los héroes (2B, 9S y 2A) muestra un nuevo lado de NieR, a veces sorprendente, y presenta nuevas mecánicas de juego. Aunque solo hay un arsenal compartido entre los tres, es extremadamente diverso, con más de 30 tipos de armas cuerpo a cuerpo. Cada arma tiene su propia cadena de combos que se desarrolla a medida que aumentas su nivel. También hay una amplia variedad de apoyo de fuego en forma de unidades tácticas Pod, que también sirven como medio de comunicación e intercambio de información con el Búnker, la base de androides en órbita.

Para una experiencia de juego más cómoda, hay una gran cantidad de chips (en su mayoría habilidades pasivas) que puedes utilizar para personalizar tu estilo de juego según tus preferencias y necesidades.

Las peleas en sí son dinámicas y coloridas, y las rápidas esquivas con cambios de espacio agregan un toque de elegancia cinematográfica, dándote la ilusión de inmortalidad.

La música en el juego es un ejemplo perfecto de cómo complementar la experiencia visual y narrativa. Cada composición está llena de sentimiento y enfatiza lo que sucede en la pantalla de una manera impactante, haciendo que tus dedos se estremezcan de emoción. Llevo semanas escuchando las composiciones de NieR y es imposible elegir una favorita (aunque estoy obsesionado con "End of the Unknown").

Como es evidente por todo lo mencionado anteriormente, me encanta NieR en todos sus aspectos y enfoques. Por lo general, cuando disfrutas de un juego, en algún momento encuentras al menos una pequeña imperfección. 

En NieR hubo tiempo para maravillarme explorando un mundo lujoso, emocionarme con la música, reír, llorar, enamorarme y, finalmente, comprender que este juego no se olvidará fácilmente...

141785780.review:
Full disclosure: This has been my thoughts after two [W] (joke) endings, playing with KB&M.
Desperately wanted to enjoy this, and I'm sure it's a fantastic experience if you're looking for one.
But I have to address the absolute impossibility of playing this on a keyboard: Even from the very beginning, any top-down section is an absolute mental effort to use WASD and arrows at the same time, while also managing extra presses like firing and dodging.
The camera usage is definitely thought out, but as someone who is used to having fully camera control it is both infuriating and disorienting to manage: The game certainly does its best to make the angles work, but in 3D sections with enemies surrounding you, it is too much to try and wrangle the camera to see what is going on, especially at the same time as the combat.
The bullet hell aspect is definitely interesting, but simply not manageable with all the other problems one has to worry about in fights.
And finally, the reason I'm here instead of trying to get better: Dying (at least in the prologue) sets you back to the very beginning. I can possibly learn Marx's (subtle name, I know) attacks under ideal circumstances, but I can't be bothered to experiment when every failure sets me back to redo 20 minutes of tutorial (and the twin-stick-designed sections).

If you just want the experience, watch the anime instead.

141640779.review:
This game,, it's broken me down time and time again, ripped my heart to shreds and left me heartbroken, but at the same time, it's brought me back up again. Terrible things happen, and people suffer for what seems like no reason. Yes, this world is terrible, but it's also very beautiful, and it's worth fighting for. 

Real talk tho, the story is absolutely phenomenal. The graphics and music comp are beautiful (astounding, really), and the game play is satisfying and challenging. The game play switches between hack-and-slash. shoot-em-up, and even some bullet-hell type stuff, but it blends and seams together perfectly. To get the full experience of the story, you'll have to play through it at least 3 times, but I swear to you, it's worth it. Just stick through it to the end, listen to the different stories the game offers you. Each story is just as impactful and heart-wrenching as the last.

Some spoiler territory following, but nothing too specific:

[spoiler] I wanted to 100% complete the game. Get every single fish, item, pod, weapon upgrade, quest, every ending. And I got pretty far too. Maybe about 80% completion overall. But then I was left with one last decision by one of the final endings (E). And you know what? I might regret that decision in the future, but I came to the realization that nothing really lasts forever. And I realized that I was ready to part with everything I had worked so hard for in the game, so I did. And I hope it ends up helping someone in the long run, as others have helped me during my play-through. [/spoiler]

This is one of the best games I've ever played in my life. It is something that I will never be able to experience for the first time ever again. And I hope that this review can get others to at least give it a try.

I also want to thank anyone and everyone who has ever sacrificed to help a total stranger, even one you might hate. [spoiler] Thank you Zhang, for your sacrifice. It really meant a lot to me. [/spoiler]

Kiwi [My voice may never reach you. But... I'm rooting for you.] - Pascal's Village

141612140.review:
The first time I purchased this game was back in 2017, on its release date (PS4 version), because the trailers at the time had hyped me up a lot.

When I started the game for the first time, it didn't take more than 2-3 hours before I ejected the game from the console and decided to resell it because the gameplay didn't convince me much, and the story in the early hours of the game didn't grab me either... How foolish I was.

I'd like to start with two 'negative' aspects of the game, in my personal opinion:

You can't run. The character we control is fairly fast, and we have a dash that we can spam. As we progress in the game, we unlock mounts that allow us to traverse the game map more quickly, but YOU CAN'T RUN in an open-world game. I'd like to know the opinions of people who have played the game, but this 'lack' bothered me a lot.
There's a lot of backtracking to be done. Often, we'll discover places or objects that we can't access unless we control a specific character. During the story or while exploring, we'll come across NPCs, crates, or similar things that we can't interact with unless we control a certain character. So, we have to keep in mind the uncovered points and return to them when we have the opportunity with the appropriate character. From an objective point of view, it's not bad; it's something found in many games. But from a subjective point of view, it's something that annoyed me quite a bit.
I played and completed this game in 2023 (6 years after its release), and the only thing I have to say is that I regret not having played it earlier.

This game has a powerful story and lore. I finished it today, and I'm shocked by everything that happened. The characters are incredibly well done, as is the world-building, and it tackles several more or less profound themes, but it does so excellently.

To complete the base story of the game, you have to do 4 runs with 4 different endings: A/B and C/D.

Each run is different from the others and only provides us with more information about what is happening, why it is happening, and parts of the game world will be modified as the runs progress... I don't want to go into detail because I don't want to spoil anything.

I have no idea how many endings there are in this game (I'll find out later), but there are many to discover. Sometimes they are troll endings (very amusing and well done), while others add important pieces to the plot (so far, I've managed to unlock 4 or 5 besides the main ones).

Contrary to many open-world games from the old and new generations, here, exploration is almost always rewarded. You can find weapons, cosmetics, data that help us better understand the story, etc. It's not like in Assassin's Creed, where a chest might contain crap that could drop from a common enemy.

It's always worth doing ALL the side missions (based on my experience, the only other open-world game that gave me this feeling was The Witcher 3) because once they are completed, you will always discover something more about the game world, unique rewards will be given, things that we normally wouldn't have access to will be unlocked, or even alternative endings will be provided. So, doing them will NEVER be a waste of time.

Without taking anything away from other parts of the game, the one that personally touched me the most is Pascal's story. I couldn't hold back a tear at that moment.

In my opinion, this title should be one of the games that everyone should play at least once in their life. I recommend buying it at full price to support the developers, but it's up to you to decide whether to do that, wait for discounts to purchase it, or get it from a key website. The important thing is that you play it.

My biggest mistake back then was judging and underestimating it based on the first 2-3 hours of gameplay. I hope you won't do the same because it truly has a lot to offer.

To conclude, I'd like to talk about the 'E' ending. It was magical to be able to destroy the credits, and it's something I haven't seen in any video game since Devil May Cry.

Rating: 9/10

This game is super complex, well written and makes you question the human condition and sentience of robots. The game has so much replay value and it is highly recommended you replay to get the real final endings. Of the 5 main endings, the final is so beautiful and well worth it to get. The other joke endings are also very fun to get but for anyone who has played Replicant, one of the endings may be worth the hard grind to get. 
It honestly is my favourite game of all time, with it's complexity and characters with so much depth you will probably grow very attached to each of the main protagonists. 
The gameplay is also very fun. One of the best things in this game is being able to evade as it makes combat very satisfying weaving in combos and evading, then either robot pew or more hacking and slashing. The other type of combat during the second playthrough is also very fun and mixes up how you play.
The music in this game is so well made and I've definitely listened it to outside of the game. However, when you do hear songs in game while you play it becomes the most hype thing ever. Interesting when you do the second playthrough combat, the music changes and it's a vibe.
Overall, the game is perfection or close to perfection. A solid 10/10 or my rating 11/10.

What doesnt work is that this game's world is extremely empty, it's so barebones it almost feels like a bug or something. I thought a few times that enemies or assets had failed to load because it was so barren. This just feels cheap to me, I don't want to sit through / force myself  to play the same game multiple times with slight differences (Route A / B) just to experience the good part (Route C). 141266504.review:
[h1] Overrated [/h1]

I'll preface my review by saying that this style of action game is perhaps not for me and I obviously haven't finished the entire thing (...but why would you continue to play something if you're not enjoying it after nearly 9 hours...?). Though I have had a lot of fun playing through DMC titles back during the PS2 golden era, and I'm no stranger to punishing titles like Dark Souls or Hollow Knight, this game feels so bland...

Starting with the superficial, it's not a very visually exciting world. Aside from the amusement park, the world is uninspired and devoid of detail. The character models look great and are very well animated, but they're in total contrast to the incredibly muddy and repetitive textures everywhere else.

The combat is fine, plenty of weapon variety and skills to choose from, but it's nothing special. Every encounter plays out essentially the same way.

The difficulty scaling is ridiculous. Normal difficulty level is boring, button mashing is all that's required to progress. Hard difficulty is absurd... the majority of enemies can basically one-hit kill you... and yet that's what 'Very hard' explicitly states - one hit to die. So then, why make 'Hard' difficulty essentially the same thing? On Normal difficulty, you can kill enemies that are 20 levels higher than you without too much trouble. On Hard, you get annihilated by enemies that are even 1-2 levels lower than you if you're not paying the utmost attention. 

What exacerbates the nonsensical difficulty scaling even more is the death system. People online seem to compare the death system to that of Dark Souls. That's just objectively incorrect. Dark Souls titles punish a death by potentially erasing any 'un-banked' 'exp/cash'. You [b] still [/b] have your equipment and your stats (stats that are baked into your character and have a much greater bearing on your build and the difficulty). Death in Nier is FAR more punishing. If you die in Nier, you lose all of your chips which cost a fortune to buy and upgrade. In Nier, your chips are by far the most important part of a build. Without those chips, you are [b] massively [/b] weakened, and should you die attempting to retrieve them (very likely on Hard difficulty), They're all gone - I hope you enjoying grinding mobs! It's just pointless and unnecessarily punishing...

I will refrain from commenting on the story, as that is surely something that needs to be appreciated from at least one completion.

[b] Climbing ladders was fun! [/b]

141254633.review:
NieR:Automata is a game that perfectly balances brilliant storytelling, game-play, design, and replay value while entrancing the player with its profound lore, philosophy, music, and stellar voice acting. For these reasons, I can confidently say this is one of the greatest, if not THE greatest game ever made.

For being a sequel, it's presentation of its story is so well done you won't need to have played the predecessor Nier Replicant. Yet the way the story is understandable both with and without playing Replicant, it can usually drive you to play the first Nier just based on how good it felt to experience Automata. 

The game-play balances hack-and-slash, bullet hell, retro mini-games, and a mix of all the former in a unique and incredibly fun way. On the surface, it may seem repetitive and uninspired with games like the Devil May Cry series or Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance being staples of the hack-and-slash genre. Despite, all that being said, Automata perfected hack-and-slash with other game genres in a rewarding and enticing manner done like no other game.

The design is simply impeccable. While the game depends heavily on a good operating system (namely your GPU), the landscapes, character models, areas, and effects are brilliant if your system handles it. 

The voice acting of Automata is some of the greatest ever performed in both English and Japanese Every voice actor nails their role and the performance of 9S's English voice actor is genuinely the best video game voice acting performance ever.

The music is yet another fantastic part of the Nier franchise. Not only does it tend to fit with the story, it adapts to the game and evolves to your situation. The chaos language and having both narrative value and being beautifully composed make for one of the most gorgeous soundtracks across all MEDIA. Only rivaled to it's predecessor Replicant.

The game has tons of replay value with its various endings and three routes. It builds upon it's story with the fact so much is left up to player interpretation. Not in a confusing and disappointing way but rather an interesting approach that leads you to delve deep into the lore and full understanding of it's lore and narrative.

In conclusion, I highly recommend NieR:Automata. This game is one of the most emotionally touching and well written video games ever. 

Final Rating: 10/10

141229356.review:
Now that I have finished my first playthrough and have obtained endings A - E, I can wholeheartedly say that NieR: Automata™ is a wonderful game with an enthralling story and an absolutely stunning sountrack.
However, that is not to say it is without issues...

Pros:
- Great gameplay
- Phenomenal soundtrack
- In-depth characters
- Stunning visuals

Cons:
- While the visuals are great in most areas, certain areas are rather sub-par, but given that this game was made for consoles, that is to be expected.
- This may just be personal preference, but I found the voice-acting to be rather bland and boring in many parts of the game. However, this may be on purpose to juxtapose the serious parts, and to emphasize the fact that the characters are robots.
- Due to this being originally intended for consoles, the PC port of this game has some serious bugs exclusive to this version, such as crashes that require you to either turn the graphics to the minimum or download third-party mods to overcome. However, this is a problem with the port, not the game.



So in summary, if you are looking for an emotional roller-coaster that really knows how to pull the player in like no other, I highly recommend you give NieR: Automata™ a try.
Although it may be a good idea to wait until the Summer Sale or the holiday season, for those are the times the game goes on sale.
You may also want to consider purchasing one of the console ports if possible, as to avoid the previously-mentioned bugs exclusive to this version.

The game can be surprisingly challenging but not unfair. Overall the gameplay and story are both great at 6 hours in and the only complaint I have is that the quest system can be a little confusing at times.

Character customization is uniquely fun and something I think is best discovered by playing the game. Many normal game functions like saving or character customization are made to feel a part of the world instead of a  game element.

If you love ARPG games, this is a must pickup.
